Names or lists of employees provided to the Board in connection with an election under this title are not subject to disclosure in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: Thirty days before providing an employee’s name, addresses, telephone numbers, and work information to an exclusive representative, the employer shall notify the employee of the provisions of this section.

The employee may, within 15 days of the employer’s notice under paragraph (1) of this subsection, notify the employer that the employee does not want the employee’s name, addresses, telephone numbers, or work information to be provided to an exclusive representative.

If an employee provides timely notification to the employer under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the employer may not provide the employee’s name, addresses, telephone numbers, or work information.
The notification of an employee to the employer under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall remain in effect until the employee otherwise notifies the employer.

subsection.text: An incumbent exclusive representative for a bargaining unit that is the subject of an election under § 3–405 of this title may not request or receive any employee information as provided under subsections (a) and (b) of this section.

An employer may charge an exclusive representative a fee not to exceed the actual cost of providing a list of employees’ names, addresses, telephone numbers, and work information to the exclusive representative.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an exclusive representative shall consider the information that it receives under this section as confidential and may not release the information to any person.

An exclusive representative may authorize third party contractors to use the information that it receives under this section, as directed by the exclusive representative, to carry out the exclusive representative’s statutory duties under this title.
An exclusive representative may not use the information that it receives under this section for the purpose of increasing employee membership in an employee organization.
An exclusive representative may use the information that it receives under this section only to carry out its statutory duties under this title.

subsection.text: If a person fails to comply with an order issued by the Board, a member of the Board may petition the circuit court to order the person to comply with the Board’s order.
The Board shall not be required to post bond in an action under subsection (a) of this section.
Employees subject to this title have the right to:

paragraph.text: take part or refrain from taking part in forming, joining, supporting, or participating in any employee organization or its lawful activities;
be fairly represented by their exclusive representative, if any, in collective bargaining; and
except as provided in §§ 3-303 and 3-305 of this subtitle, engage in other concerted activities for the purpose of collective bargaining or other mutual aid or protection.

subsection.text: An employee who is a member of a bargaining unit with an exclusive representative may, without the intervention of an employee organization, discuss any matter with the employer.

section.text: The State, through its appropriate officers and employees, has the right to:

subparagraph.text: determine the mission, budget, organization, numbers, types and grades of employees assigned, the work projects, tours of duty, methods, means, and personnel by which its operations are to be conducted, technology needed, internal security practices, and relocation of its facilities; and
maintain and improve the efficiency and effectiveness of governmental operations;

paragraph.text: determine the:

subparagraph.text: services to be rendered, operations to be performed, and technology to be utilized; and
overall methods, processes, means, and classes of work or personnel by which governmental operations are to be conducted;

paragraph.text: hire, direct, supervise, and assign employees;

subparagraph.text: promote, demote, discipline, discharge, retain, and lay off employees; and
terminate employment because of lack of funds, lack of work, under conditions where the employer determines continued work would be inefficient or nonproductive, or for other legitimate reasons;

paragraph.text: set the qualifications of employees for appointment and promotion, and set standards of conduct;
promulgate State or Department rules, regulations, or procedures;
provide a system of merit employment according to the standard of business efficiency; and
take actions, not otherwise specified in this section to carry out the mission of the employer.

In this section, “strike” means any concerted action to impede the full and proper performance of employment duties in order to induce, influence, coerce, or enforce demands for a change in wages, hours, terms, or other conditions of employment.
“Strike” includes a total or partial:

subparagraph.text: refusal or failure to report to work;
refusal or failure to perform employment duties;
withdrawal from work;
work stoppage; or
work slowdown.

subsection.text: State employees are prohibited from engaging in any strike.
An appointing authority may take disciplinary action, including termination of employment, against an employee who participates in a strike.
The Board shall revoke the certification of an exclusive representative who engages in any strike activity in violation of this section.
In this section, “lockout” means action taken by an employer to:

paragraph.text: interrupt or prevent the continuity of the employees’ usual work for the purpose and with the intent of coercing the employees into relinquishing rights guaranteed by this title; or
bring economic pressure on employees for the purpose of securing the agreement of their exclusive representative to certain collective bargaining agreement terms.

subsection.text: The State is prohibited from engaging in any lockout.
In the event a strike occurs or appears imminent, the State may petition the circuit court for appropriate relief, including injunction.
In the event a lockout occurs or appears imminent, the employee organization involved may petition the circuit court for appropriate relief, including injunction.
The State and its officers, employees, agents, or representatives are prohibited from engaging in any unfair labor practice, including:

paragraph.text: interfering with, restraining, or coercing employees in the exercise of their rights under this title;
dominating, interfering with, contributing financial or other support to, or assisting in the formation, existence, or administration of any labor organization;

granting administrative leave to employees to attend employer sponsored or supported meetings or events relating to an election under § 3-405 of this title, unless the employer grants employees at least the same amount of administrative leave to attend labor organization sponsored or supported meetings or employee meetings;
discriminating in hiring, tenure, or any term or condition of employment to encourage or discourage membership in an employee organization;

discharging or discriminating against an employee because of the signing or filing of an affidavit, petition, or complaint, or giving information or testimony in connection with matters under this subtitle;
failing to provide all employee organizations involved in an election the same rights of access as prescribed by the Board through regulation;
engaging in surveillance of union activities;
refusing to bargain in good faith; or
engaging in a lockout.

subsection.text: Employee organizations and their agents or representatives are prohibited from engaging in any unfair labor practice, including:

paragraph.text: interfering with, restraining, or coercing employees in the exercise of their rights under this title;
causing or attempting to cause an employer to discriminate in hiring, tenure, or any term or condition of employment to encourage or discourage membership in an employee organization;
engaging in, inducing, or encouraging any person to engage in a strike, as defined in § 3-303(a) of this subtitle;
interfering with the statutory duties of the State or an employer;
refusing to bargain in good faith; or
not fairly representing employees in collective bargaining or in any other matter in which the employee organization has the duty of fair representation.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the Board shall conduct an election for an exclusive representative of a bargaining unit if:

paragraph.text: a valid petition is filed in accordance with § 3-402 of this subtitle; and
the bargaining unit involved in the petition is determined to be an appropriate bargaining unit under § 3-403 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board may not conduct an election for an exclusive representative of a bargaining unit if the Board has conducted an election or certified an exclusive representative for that bargaining unit within the preceding 2 years.
A petition for the election of an exclusive representative of a bargaining unit may be filed with the Board by:

paragraph.text: an employee organization seeking certification as an exclusive representative; or
an employee, a group of employees, or an employee organization seeking a new election to determine an exclusive representative.

subsection.text: A petition shall:

paragraph.text: contain the information the Board requires; and

be accompanied by a showing of interest supported by 30% of the employees in the appropriate unit indicating their desire to be exclusively represented by the petitioner for the purpose of collective bargaining.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, the Board shall determine the appropriateness of each bargaining unit.
If there is no dispute about the appropriateness of the establishment of the bargaining unit, the Board shall issue an order defining an appropriate bargaining unit.
If there is a dispute about the appropriateness of the establishment of the bargaining unit, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: conduct a hearing; and
issue an order defining an appropriate bargaining unit.

subsection.text: If the appropriate bargaining unit as determined by the Board differs from the bargaining unit described in the petition, the Board may:

paragraph.text: dismiss the petition; or
direct an election in the appropriate bargaining unit if the signatures included in the petition include those of at least 30% of the employees in the appropriate bargaining unit.

subsection.text: A bargaining unit shall consist only of employees defined in regulations adopted by the Secretary and not specifically excluded by § 3-102(b) of this title.

paragraph.text: Each system institution, Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, and Baltimore City Community College shall have separate bargaining units.
The presidents of the system institutions may agree to cooperate for the purpose of collective bargaining:

subparagraph.text: before the election of exclusive representatives; or
after the certification of exclusive representatives under § 3-406(a) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Appropriate bargaining units shall consist of:

subparagraph.text: all eligible nonexempt employees, as described in the federal Fair Labor Standards Act, except eligible sworn police officers;
all eligible exempt employees, as described in the federal Fair Labor Standards Act; and
all eligible sworn police officers.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee shall have the authority to assign classification titles and positions to bargaining units as appropriate.
The following individuals and entities shall assign classification titles and positions to bargaining units at the following institutions:

subparagraph.text: at a system institution, the President of the system institution; and
at Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, or Baltimore City Community College, the governing board of the institution.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, Maryland Transportation Authority police officers at the rank of first sergeant and below shall have a separate bargaining unit.

section.text: Each employee organization that seeks certification as an exclusive representative shall file with the Board:

paragraph.text: a copy of the employee organization’s governing documents, which:

subparagraph.text: give individual members the right to participate in activities of the organization;
require periodic elections by secret ballot that are conducted with recognized safeguards to ensure the equal rights of all members to nominate, seek office, and vote in the elections;
direct full and accurate accounting of all income and expenses using standard accounting methods; and
require an annual report that is made available to all members of the appropriate bargaining unit; and

paragraph.text: a certification that the organization:

subparagraph.text: accepts members without regard to any factor in § 2-302(b) of this article; and
will deny membership only to an employee for a reason that is acceptable to the Board.

paragraph.text: Within 5 days of determination that a valid petition has been submitted, the Board shall notify interested employee organizations of the pending election petition.

Within 10 days of determination that a valid petition has been submitted under § 3-402 of this subtitle or subsection (c)(2)(iii) of this section, the Department shall make available to all interested employee organizations reasonable and equivalent means to communicate by mail and in person with each employee in the appropriate bargaining unit for the purpose of soliciting the employee’s vote in an election held under this section.

subsection.text: An election shall be held in any unit within 90 days after the filing of a valid petition for election in such unit in accordance with guidelines established by the Board.

paragraph.text: All elections shall be conducted by secret ballot.
The Board shall place the following choices on the ballot:

subparagraph.text: the name of the exclusive representative, if any;
the name of the employee organization designated in the petition filed under § 3-402 of this subtitle with respect to an appropriate bargaining unit;

the name of each employee organization designated in a petition filed with the Board, within 15 days of notice of the pending election petition, that includes the signatures of at least 10% of the employees in the appropriate bargaining unit; and
a provision for “no exclusive representative”.

subsection.text: If none of the choices on a ballot receives a majority of the votes cast in an election, the Board shall conduct a runoff election between the choices that received the two highest number of votes in the election.
The Board shall certify as exclusive representative the employee organization receiving the votes in an election from a majority of the employees voting in the election.
After notice and an opportunity for a hearing, the Board may deny or revoke certification as exclusive representative of an employee organization for willful failure to comply with:

paragraph.text: this title; or
the governing documents of the organization.

section.text: An employee organization certified as the exclusive representative shall:

paragraph.text: serve as the sole and exclusive bargaining agent for all employees in the bargaining unit;

represent fairly and without discrimination all employees in the bargaining unit, whether or not the employees are members of the employee organization or are paying dues or other contributions to it or participating in its affairs; and
promptly file with the Board all changes and amendments to the organization’s governing documents.
The following individuals or entities shall designate one or more representatives to participate as a party in collective bargaining on behalf of the State or the following institutions:

subparagraph.text: on behalf of the State, the Governor;
on behalf of a system institution, the president of the system institution; and
on behalf of Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, or Baltimore City Community College, the governing board of the institution.

paragraph.text: The exclusive representative shall designate one or more representatives to participate as a party in collective bargaining on behalf of the exclusive representative.

subsection.text: The parties shall meet at reasonable times and engage in collective bargaining in good faith to conclude a written memorandum of understanding or other written understanding as defined under § 3-101(c)(1)(ii) of this title.

paragraph.text: The parties shall make every reasonable effort to conclude negotiations in a timely manner for inclusion by the principal unit in its budget request to the Governor.

subparagraph.text: The parties shall conclude negotiations before January 1 for any item requiring an appropriation of funds for the fiscal year that begins on the following July 1.

In the budget bill submitted to the General Assembly, the Governor shall include any amounts in the budgets of the principal units required to accommodate any additional cost resulting from the negotiations, including the actuarial impact of any legislative changes to any of the State pension or retirement systems that are required, as a result of the negotiations, for the fiscal year beginning the following July 1 if the legislative changes have been negotiated to become effective in that fiscal year.
If the parties do not conclude negotiations for the next fiscal year before October 25, either party may request that a fact finder be employed to resolve the issues.
The fact finder shall be employed no later than November 1.
A fact finder shall be a neutral party appointed by alternate striking from a list by the parties provided:

sub-subparagraph.text: by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service; or
under the Labor Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association.

subparagraph.text: The fact finder:

sub-subparagraph.text: may give notice and hold hearings in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act;
may administer oaths and take testimony and other evidence;
may issue subpoenas; and
before November 20, shall make written recommendations regarding wages, hours, and working conditions, and any other terms or conditions of employment that may be in dispute.

subparagraph.text: The written recommendations of the fact finder shall be delivered to the Governor, the exclusive representative, the President of the Senate, and the Speaker of the House of Delegates by the Secretary on or before December 1.

paragraph.text: A memorandum of understanding that incorporates all matters of agreement reached by the parties shall be executed by the exclusive representative and:

subparagraph.text: for a memorandum of understanding relating to the State, the Governor or the Governor’s designee;
for a memorandum of understanding relating to a system institution, the president of the system institution or the president’s designee; and

for a memorandum of understanding relating to Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, or Baltimore City Community College, the governing board of the institution or the governing board’s designee.

paragraph.text: To the extent these matters require legislative approval or the appropriation of funds, the matters shall be recommended to the General Assembly for approval or for the appropriation of funds.
To the extent matters involving a State institution of higher education require legislative approval, the legislation shall be recommended to the Governor for submission to the General Assembly.

subsection.text: Negotiations for a memorandum of understanding shall be considered closed sessions under § 10-508 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: The terms of a memorandum of understanding executed by the Governor or the Governor’s designee and an exclusive representative of a bargaining unit for skilled service or professional service employees in the State Personnel Management System are not applicable to employees of a State institution of higher education.

The terms of a memorandum of understanding executed by a president of a system institution or the governing board of Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, or Baltimore City Community College, or their respective designees, and the exclusive representative of a bargaining unit for employees of a State institution of higher education are not applicable to skilled service or professional service employees in the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: Collective bargaining shall include all matters relating to wages, hours, and other terms and conditions of employment.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, collective bargaining may include negotiations relating to the right of an employee organization to receive service fees from nonmembers.
An employee whose religious beliefs are opposed to joining or financially supporting any collective bargaining organization is:

subparagraph.text: not required to pay a service fee; and

required to pay an amount of money as determined in collective bargaining negotiations, not to exceed any service fee negotiated under paragraph (1) of this subsection, to any charitable organization exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and to furnish to the Department and the exclusive representative written proof of such payment.

paragraph.text: Collective bargaining between an employee organization and a system institution, Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, or Baltimore City Community College may not include negotiations relating to the right of an employee organization to receive service fees from nonmembers.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, the representatives of the State, a system institution, Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, and Baltimore City Community College:

paragraph.text: shall not be required to negotiate over any matter that is inconsistent with applicable law; and

may negotiate and reach agreement with regard to any such matter only if it is understood that the agreement with respect to such matter cannot become effective unless the applicable law is amended by the General Assembly.
A memorandum of understanding shall contain all matters of agreement reached in the collective bargaining process.
The memorandum shall be in writing and signed by the exclusive representative involved in the collective bargaining negotiations and:

subparagraph.text: for a memorandum of understanding relating to the State, the Governor or the Governor’s designee;
for a memorandum of understanding relating to a system institution, the president of the system institution or the president’s designee; and

for a memorandum of understanding relating to Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, or Baltimore City Community College, the governing board of the institution or the governing board’s designee.

subsection.text: No memorandum of understanding is valid if it extends for less than 1 year or for more than 3 years.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a memorandum of understanding is not effective until it is ratified by the Governor and a majority of the votes cast by the employees in the bargaining unit.

In the case of a State institution of higher education, a memorandum of understanding is not effective until it is ratified by the institution’s governing board and a majority of the votes cast by the employees in the bargaining unit.

section.text: The president of a system institution may elect to terminate a cooperation agreement with another system institution, entered into for the purpose of collective bargaining with exclusive representatives, effective on the termination date of the memorandum of understanding between the exclusive representatives and the system institutions that are parties to the cooperation agreement.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall carry out those provisions of this Division I that are subject to the authority of the Secretary.

The Secretary is responsible for the operation of the Department and shall establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient administration of the Department. The Secretary may establish, reorganize, or abolish areas of responsibility in the Department as necessary to fulfill effectively the duties assigned to the Secretary.
The Secretary is responsible for establishing policy to be followed by the units in the Department.
To carry out those provisions of this Division I that are subject to the authority of the Secretary, the Secretary may adopt regulations, guidelines, or policies.

After consultation with the Office of Administrative Hearings, the Secretary shall adopt regulations governing peer review panels, that include procedures for a principal unit to establish peer review panels as an alternative mechanism for dispute resolution under Titles 11 and 12 of this article.

section.text: For efficiency and economy in State government, the Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: conduct reviews of positions in the State Personnel Management System; and
recommend to the appointing authority a plan of reorganization, reassignment, or elimination of the positions reviewed.

subsection.text: As to matters subject to the authority of the Secretary, the Secretary periodically shall conduct investigations and, as necessary, visits to various units to determine:

paragraph.text: the enforcement and effect of this Division I and the regulations adopted under it;
the conduct of employees in the State Personnel Management System;
the nature, tenure, and compensation of all positions in the State Personnel Management System;
the appropriateness of position classifications by appointing authorities;
whether the duties performed by an employee conform to the duties listed for that employee's class;
the methods of administration of the State Personnel Management System; and
any other information that might help the Secretary to administer this Division I.

subsection.text: In conducting an investigation under this section, the Secretary may require any employee in the State Personnel Management System to appear before the Secretary or the Secretary's designee and give evidence.

As part of any investigation or hearing under this Division I, the Secretary or the person that the Secretary designates to conduct the investigation or hearing may administer oaths, take testimony and other evidence, and subpoena any person or any relevant document.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena or refuses to be sworn or to testify, then, on complaint of the Secretary, a circuit court may order the person to comply with the subpoena, to be sworn, or to testify.
This section does not apply to those units of State government with an independent personnel system.
In the State Personnel Management System the Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: establish classes;
assign a rate of pay to each class;
ensure that each class comprises one or more positions:

subparagraph.text: that are similar in their duties and responsibilities;
that are similar in the general qualifications required to perform those duties and responsibilities;
to which the same standards and, if required, tests of fitness can be applied; and
to which the same rates of pay can be applied;

paragraph.text: give each class a descriptive classification title;
prepare a description of each class; and

subparagraph.text: create additional classes; and
abolish, combine, or modify existing classes.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: assign a class to the skilled service, professional service, management service, or executive service, as appropriate; and
designate special appointment positions in the State Personnel Management System that:

subparagraph.text: must be filled without regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion; or
in accordance with § 6–405(b) of this article, may be filled with regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion.

section.text: The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: classify skilled service positions, professional service positions, management service positions, and executive service positions;
establish standards and general procedures to be used to classify positions in the skilled service, professional service, management service, and executive service; and
provide advice and guidance on the use of those standards and procedures.

The Secretary may delegate authority to the head of a principal unit to classify positions for the principal unit in accordance with standards and procedures established by the Secretary in accordance with § 4–202(2) of this subtitle.
If the Secretary delegates classification authority to the head of a principal unit under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the head of the principal unit shall:

subparagraph.text: submit for the Secretary’s approval a position classification plan for classifying positions in the principal unit that are in the skilled service, professional service, and management service; and
classify skilled service positions, professional service positions, and management service positions in the principal unit in accordance with the approved classification plan.

paragraph.text: Each employee in a position shall assume the classification title given the class to which that position belongs.
The Secretary, the Comptroller, and the Treasurer shall use these classification titles in all relevant records and communications.

subsection.text: To ensure that positions in the State Personnel Management System are classified properly, the Secretary:

paragraph.text: shall conduct position classification audits at least once every 3 years for any classification activity performed in accordance with subsection (a)(2) of this section; and
may conduct operational audits of classification practices and records in principal units at least once every 3 years.

subsection.text: The Secretary may:

paragraph.text: classify positions in a unit when, in the Secretary's judgment, it is necessary to preserve the integrity of the classification system; and
order the head of a principal unit to:

subparagraph.text: take appropriate action to properly classify a position or take other appropriate action to comply with a position classification audit; or
modify the unit's classification practices to comply with the findings of an operational audit.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall determine the effective dates for newly created or modified classes, position classification plans, and classification standards and procedures.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to provide for effective dates of position reclassifications.

section.text: If there is a material change in the duties of a position, the Secretary shall abolish the position and create a new position in its place.

On or before October 15 of each year, each unit of the Executive Branch of State government shall submit to the Secretary the information that the Secretary requires on the processing and disposition during the preceding fiscal year of each:

paragraph.text: denial of a pay increase;
disciplinary suspension;
grievance;
involuntary demotion;
rejection on probation; and
attendance incentive award and conversion made pursuant to Title 9, Subtitle 12 of this article.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to the University System of Maryland.

The Secretary shall submit to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly an annual report covering all units of the Executive Branch of State government, including a unit with an independent personnel system, for each fiscal year that:

paragraph.text: provides information about:

subparagraph.text: employee performance and efficiency;
use of leave by State employees;
incentive awards;
whistleblower proceedings;
each denial of a pay increase, each disciplinary suspension, each grievance, each involuntary demotion, and each rejection on probation; and
a summary of the equal employment opportunity report required under § 5–204 of this article, including hiring, firing, promotions, terminations, and rejections on probation, by race, sex, and age;

paragraph.text: provides statistics and rankings that compare minority group State employees to all State employees in all job categories;
provides information about part–time work and, in the Secretary’s discretion, alternate work schedules, work days, and work locations;
provides information on the total number of positions designated as special appointments, including special appointments designated with regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion; and
makes any recommendations about conditions in State employment that the Secretary considers advisable.

subsection.text: The report required by this section shall be submitted on or before January 1 following the fiscal year to which it applies.
On the request of a unit of State government, the Secretary, consistent with available resources, shall offer assistance to the unit in personnel and employee relations matters.

paragraph.text: On request to the Secretary, the Department, consistent with available resources, shall assist any county or municipal corporation of the State that adopts a merit system for its employees, so that merit systems may be administered throughout the State without unnecessary expense.
The Department shall assist the county or municipal corporation making the request by:

subparagraph.text: helping to test candidates for positions;
helping to prepare regulations; and
making available the full use of the facilities of the Department.
Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the Department shall provide the assistance required by this subsection without charge.

A county or municipal corporation shall reimburse the Department for travel and other expenses that the Department incurs because of the use of departmental facilities by that county or municipal corporation.

subsection.text: On request of the Secretary, all employees and officers of the State shall assist the Department in all proper ways in carrying out this Division I and the regulations, guidelines, and policies adopted under it. This assistance shall be provided as a public duty and without extra compensation.
On request of the Secretary, all employees and officers of the State or of a county or municipal corporation of the State shall:

paragraph.text: allow the Department reasonable use of public buildings for tests or investigations under this Division I;
provide heat and light for the public buildings used by the Department under this subsection; and
in all other proper ways, facilitate the work of the Department.

section.text: The Office of Administrative Hearings shall dispose of a case or conduct a hearing and issue a final decision in:

paragraph.text: a Whistleblower Law hearing under § 5–310 of this article;
an appeal under Title 11 of this article of a disciplinary action;
a grievance under § 12–205 of this article; and
an appeal under § 18–123 of the Public Utilities Article for the removal of an employee of the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.

section.text: The head of each principal unit shall notify the employees in the unit of the location, at the work site, of a copy of:

paragraph.text: this Division I of this article; and
all applicable personnel policies, guidelines, and regulations.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Coordinator” means the Equal Employment Opportunity Coordinator.
“Program” means the Equal Employment Opportunity Program established under this subtitle.
“Unit” means a unit of the Executive Branch of State government.
There is an Equal Employment Opportunity Program, which is under the authority of the Secretary.
The purpose of the Program is to ensure a system based on merit that provides equal opportunity in employment on the basis of merit and fitness.
The following employees and applicants for employment are included in the Program:

paragraph.text: an employee in any unit of the Executive Branch of State government, including a unit with an independent personnel system; and

an applicant for a position in the skilled service, professional service, or management service, of the State Personnel Management System or a comparable position in an independent personnel system in the Executive Branch of State government.

section.text: Except as provided in § 5–209 of this subtitle, in addition to any right to file an employment discrimination complaint with the Commission on Civil Rights, with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, or in court, an employee may elect to pursue an allegation of employment discrimination under the complaint resolution procedures of this subtitle.
The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program in compliance with all applicable State and federal laws governing equal employment opportunity;
adopt regulations, policies, and directives to implement the Program;
evaluate the equal employment efforts in each unit in the Program;
take any action necessary and permitted by law to enforce this subtitle; and
at least annually report on the Program to the Governor.

subsection.text: In accordance with the provisions and intent of the Maryland Constitution and other laws of the State, each unit shall:

paragraph.text: comply with all applicable regulations, policies, guidelines, and directives of the Secretary to carry out this section;
cooperate fully with the Coordinator in the investigation of complaints of discrimination in violation of § 5–208 of this subtitle;

subparagraph.text: in accordance with the regulations, policies, guidelines, and directives of the Secretary, annually prepare a plan that includes the development and implementation of policies and programs to ensure that protected group members are appropriately represented and that the personnel practices in the unit are not discriminatory; and
submit to the Secretary the progress reports about the plan that the Secretary requires;

paragraph.text: for each fiscal year, submit to the Coordinator by the following October 15 an annual report about the activities that the unit undertook in that fiscal year to implement the Program, including:

subparagraph.text: information about personnel practices within the unit;
a summary of complaints filed, investigated, resolved, and pending; and
information about relations with other units of State government; and

paragraph.text: provide a copy of the annual report to the Maryland Civil Rights Commission.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle, the University System of Maryland may satisfy any reporting requirement required by this subtitle or by regulations adopted under this subtitle by submitting to the Secretary an annual report on the System’s equal employment opportunity policies and programs in such format as is determined by the System’s Board of Regents.
An appointing authority shall provide each employee subject to this subtitle with a notice of:

paragraph.text: the protections and remedies against employment discrimination available to the employee under:

subparagraph.text: this subtitle;
the laws governing the Commission on Civil Rights; and
the laws governing the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission; and

paragraph.text: the applicable time limitations for filing complaints under those laws.

subsection.text: The Governor, with the advice of the Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight, shall appoint an Equal Employment Opportunity Coordinator.
The Coordinator shall:

paragraph.text: administer and enforce the Program; and
investigate and, as appropriate, resolve complaints that involve allegations of violations of this subtitle.
The head of each principal unit shall appoint:

subparagraph.text: a fair practices officer who:

sub-subparagraph.text: reports directly to the head of the unit; and
is an assistant secretary or an employee of the unit with stature similar to that of an assistant secretary; and

subparagraph.text: an appropriate number of equal employment opportunity officers for the unit.

paragraph.text: If necessary, the fair practices officer of a unit may also be the unit's equal employment opportunity officer.
All appointments under this subsection shall be made in accordance with position descriptions approved by the Secretary.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide training, assistance, and advice for equal employment opportunity officers and fair practices officers.
Each fair practices officer shall:

paragraph.text: implement the Program within the unit;
investigate and, as appropriate, resolve complaints filed under § 5-211 of this subtitle; and
coordinate activities of equal employment opportunity officers in the unit.

subsection.text: An equal employment opportunity officer shall:

paragraph.text: monitor all personnel actions adopted by the unit;

attest that procedures consistent with this article, the Governor's Code on Fair Practices, and other State and federal equal employment opportunity laws were followed by the unit in taking a personnel action; and
perform the duties assigned by the fair practices officer and any other duty required by this article.

subsection.text: An appointing authority shall delay the effective date of any adverse personnel action that directly affects an equal employment opportunity officer for up to 45 days, pending review and resolution by the Coordinator.
All personnel actions concerning an employee in the Executive Branch of State government shall be made in accordance with § 2–302 of this article.

Personnel actions concerning an employee or applicant for employment in the skilled service or professional service of the State Personnel Management System or comparable position in an independent personnel system in the Executive Branch of State government shall also be made without regard to:

paragraph.text: political affiliation, belief, or opinion; or
any other nonmerit factor.

subsection.text: All personnel actions concerning an employee or applicant in the management service shall also be made without regard to the employee’s political affiliation, belief, or opinion.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, personnel actions concerning special appointments or applicants for special appointment in the State Personnel Management System or comparable positions in an independent personnel system in the Executive Branch of State government shall be made without regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion.

For the positions that are designated by the Secretary under § 4–201(c)(2)(ii) of this article or by the Secretary of Transportation under § 2–103.4(b)(2) of the Transportation Article, personnel actions concerning special appointments or applicants for special appointment in the State Personnel Management System or comparable positions in an independent personnel system in the Executive Branch of State government may be made with regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion.

subsection.text: The protections of this section are in addition to whatever legal or constitutional protections an employee or applicant has.
An employee in the skilled service, professional service, or management service of the State Personnel Management System may elect to pursue an allegation of employment discrimination under:

paragraph.text: the complaint procedures in this subtitle; or
the grievance procedures in Title 12 of this article.

subsection.text: An employee of the University System of Maryland who is eligible to file a grievance under Title 13 of the Education Article may elect to pursue an allegation of employment discrimination under:

paragraph.text: the complaint procedures in this subtitle; or
a grievance under Title 13 of the Education Article.

subsection.text: An employee of Morgan State University who is eligible to file a grievance under Title 14 of the Education Article may elect to pursue an allegation of employment discrimination under:

paragraph.text: the complaint procedures in this subtitle; or
a grievance under Title 14 of the Education Article.

subsection.text: A complainant may be represented during the complaint process by any person the complainant chooses.

paragraph.text: If a complainant fails to appeal a decision in accordance with this subtitle, the complainant is considered to have accepted the decision.
A failure to decide a complaint in accordance with this subtitle is considered a denial from which an appeal may be made.

subsection.text: Each party shall make every effort to resolve a complaint at the lowest level possible.
An applicant or employee subject to this subtitle may file with the head of the principal unit a written complaint that alleges a violation of § 5-208 of this subtitle.
A complaint under this subtitle must be filed within 30 days after the complainant first knew of or reasonably should have known of the alleged violation that is the basis for the complaint.

section.text: Within 30 days after a complaint under § 5-211 of this subtitle is received:

paragraph.text: an equal employment officer, under the direction of the fair practices officer, shall investigate the complaint and recommend a proposed decision to the head of the principal unit; and
the head of the principal unit shall issue a written decision to the complainant and may grant any appropriate relief.

subsection.text: Within 10 days after receiving a decision under § 5-212 of this subtitle, a complainant may appeal the decision in writing to the Secretary.
Within 30 days after an appeal is received:

paragraph.text: the Coordinator:

subparagraph.text: shall review the complaint and the decision being appealed;
may conduct any necessary investigation; and
shall recommend to the Secretary or designee a finding of whether a violation of this subtitle has occurred; and

paragraph.text: the Secretary or designee shall:

subparagraph.text: take the action described in subsection (c)(1) or (c)(2) of this section; and
issue to the parties a written decision that includes notice of any remedial action taken.

paragraph.text: If the Secretary or designee determines that a violation has not occurred, the Secretary or designee shall dismiss the complaint.
If the Secretary or designee determines that a violation has occurred, the Secretary or designee shall take appropriate remedial action.

subsection.text: As remedial action for a violation of § 5-208 of this subtitle, the Secretary or designee may:

paragraph.text: order the removal of detrimental information from the complainant's State personnel records;
require the head of the principal unit to:

subparagraph.text: hire, promote, or reinstate the complainant or end the complainant's suspension from employment;
award the complainant back pay up to the day of the violation;
grant the complainant leave or seniority;
take appropriate disciplinary action against any individual who caused the violation; or
take any other remedial action that the Secretary or designee considers appropriate.

subsection.text: The decision of the Secretary or designee is final.

section.text: Information obtained as part of an investigation conducted under this subtitle is confidential within the meaning of Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article.
An employee who violates or fails to comply with this subtitle is subject to disciplinary action, including termination of employment.
This subtitle applies to all employees and State employees who are applicants for positions in the Executive Branch of State government, including a unit with an independent personnel system.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not preclude action for defamation or invasion of privacy.
This subtitle does not prohibit a personnel action that would have been taken regardless of a disclosure of information.

section.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations for processing and resolving complaints brought under this subtitle.
The head of each principal unit shall provide the employees of the unit with written notice of the protections and remedies provided by this subtitle.

Subject to the limitations of § 5-306 of this subtitle, a supervisor, appointing authority, or the head of a principal unit may not take or refuse to take any personnel action as a reprisal against an employee who:

paragraph.text: discloses information that the employee reasonably believes evidences:

subparagraph.text: an abuse of authority, gross mismanagement, or gross waste of money;
a substantial and specific danger to public health or safety; or
a violation of law; or

paragraph.text: following a disclosure under item (1) of this section seeks a remedy provided under this subtitle or any other law or policy governing the employee's unit.

section.text: Section 5-305 of this subtitle applies to a disclosure that is specifically prohibited by law only if that disclosure is made exclusively to the Attorney General in the manner allowed in § 5-313 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An employee in the State Personnel Management System who seeks relief for a violation of § 5-305 of this subtitle may elect to file:

paragraph.text: a complaint under § 5-309 of this subtitle; or
a grievance under Title 12 of this article.

subsection.text: An employee of the University System of Maryland who is eligible to file a grievance under Title 13 of the Education Article and seeks relief for a violation of § 5-305 of this subtitle may elect to file:

paragraph.text: a complaint under § 5-309 of this subtitle; or
a grievance under Title 13 of the Education Article.

subsection.text: An employee of Morgan State University who is eligible to file a grievance under Title 14 of the Education Article and seeks relief for a violation of § 5-305 of this subtitle may elect to file:

paragraph.text: a complaint under § 5-309 of this subtitle; or
a grievance under Title 14 of the Education Article.
A complainant may be represented during the complaint process by any person the complainant chooses.
Either party may be represented at a hearing by counsel.
If a complainant fails to appeal a decision in accordance with this subtitle, the complainant is considered to have accepted the decision.
A failure to decide a complaint in accordance with this subtitle is considered a denial from which an appeal may be made.

subsection.text: Each party shall make every effort to resolve a complaint at the lowest level possible.

paragraph.text: An employee subject to this subtitle may file with the Secretary a complaint that alleges a violation of § 5-305 of this subtitle.
A complaint under this subtitle must be filed within 6 months after the complainant first knew of or reasonably should have known of the violation.

subsection.text: When a complaint is received, the Secretary or designee promptly shall:

paragraph.text: send a copy of the complaint to the head of the principal unit named in the complaint; and
advise the head of the principal unit to respond in writing to the complaint within 20 days after receiving the copy.

subsection.text: Within 60 days after a complaint is received:

paragraph.text: the complaint shall be investigated to determine whether a violation of § 5-305 of this subtitle has occurred:

subparagraph.text: by the Secretary or designee of the Secretary; or
if the Department is charged in the complaint, by a designee of the Governor; and

paragraph.text: the Secretary or designee or the Governor's designee shall:

subparagraph.text: take the action described in subsection (d)(1) or (2) of this section; and
issue to the complainant and head of the principal unit a written decision that includes any remedial action taken.

paragraph.text: If the Secretary or designee or the Governor's designee determines that a violation has not occurred, the Secretary or Governor's designee shall dismiss the complaint.
If the Secretary or designee or the Governor's designee determines that a violation has occurred, the Secretary or designee shall take appropriate remedial action.

subsection.text: As a remedial action for a violation of § 5-305 of this subtitle, the Secretary or designee may:

paragraph.text: order the removal of any related detrimental information from the complainant's State personnel records;
require the head of the principal unit to:

subparagraph.text: hire, promote, or reinstate the complainant or end the complainant's suspension from employment;
award the complainant back pay to the day of the violation;
grant the complainant leave or seniority;
take appropriate disciplinary action against any individual who caused the violation; and
take any other remedial action consistent with the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A complainant may appeal to the Office of Administrative Hearings:

paragraph.text: within 10 days after receiving a decision under § 5-309 of this subtitle; or
when a decision is not issued within 60 days after the complaint is filed and the complainant requests a hearing.

The Office of Administrative Hearings shall conduct a hearing on each appeal in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article. The Office is bound by any regulation, declaratory ruling, prior adjudication, or other settled, preexisting policy, to the same extent as the Department is or would have been bound if it were hearing the case.
A record that is protected from disclosure under Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article may be used as evidence in a hearing only if:

subparagraph.text: the material is essential to the conduct of the hearing; and
names and other identifying information are deleted to the extent necessary to maintain confidentiality.

paragraph.text: The confidentiality of records and information protected from disclosure under Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article shall be maintained in each hearing.

Within 45 days after the close of the hearing record, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall issue to the parties a written decision and may grant any appropriate relief under subsection (d) of this section.
The decision of the Office of Administrative Hearings is final.

subsection.text: A complainant who prevails at a hearing may be awarded any appropriate relief, including:

paragraph.text: any remedial action allowed under § 5-309(e) of this subtitle; and
costs of litigation and reasonable attorney's fees.

subsection.text: A complainant or appointing authority may appeal the decision issued under subsection (c) of this section in accordance with § 10-222 of the State Government Article.

section.text: After reviewing a final decision under this subtitle, the court may award costs of litigation and reasonable attorney's fees to a prevailing complainant and any other appropriate relief.

If, during an investigation under § 5-309(c) of this subtitle, the Secretary or Governor's designee finds that reasonable grounds exist to believe that a crime has been committed, the Secretary or Governor's designee shall:

paragraph.text: promptly refer the matter to an appropriate prosecutor;
make all pertinent evidence available to the prosecutor; and
send to the individual believed to have committed the crime a notice that:

subparagraph.text: contains a statement of the allegation;
notifies the individual that the matter has been referred to a prosecutor;
advises the individual of the individual's right to obtain counsel; and
advises the individual of the individual's right to refuse to respond to the allegation if a response might be incriminating.

section.text: For purposes of this subtitle, the Attorney General shall:

paragraph.text: designate an assistant Attorney General to receive from applicants and employees any information the disclosure of which is otherwise protected by law;
investigate each allegation of illegality or impropriety;
take appropriate legal action; and
if the investigation concerns an allegation of illegality or impropriety in the Executive Branch, submit a confidential report to the Governor that describes the content of the disclosure.

section.text: Information obtained as part of an investigation conducted under this subtitle is confidential within the meaning of Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“State facility” has the meaning stated in § 8–306(a) of the State Government Article.
“Unit” means a unit of the Executive Branch of State government.

subsection.text: If a traumatic event occurs in a State facility of a unit and results in the death of an individual, the unit shall obtain mental health support services for any employee of the unit affected by the traumatic event.
The services required under this section shall be provided within 48 hours after the traumatic event occurs.

section.text: There is a State Personnel Management System, which is under the authority of the Secretary of Budget and Management.
The basic purpose of the State Personnel Management System is to provide a system of employment for employees under the authority of the Secretary. The State Personnel Management System:

subparagraph.text: establishes categories of service for employees based on the general nature of the employee's duties or method of appointment; and
provides procedures for the appointment, discipline, and termination of employees in each service;
groups employees into classes based on specific duties that employees perform; and
provides a system of pay for employees;

paragraph.text: provides for a system of merit employment in the skilled service and professional service, regardless of an applicant's political or religious opinions or affiliations or of any standard other than business efficiency;
provides a process for the:

subparagraph.text: promotion and training of employees; and
prompt removal of employees; and

paragraph.text: provides for other aspects of human resources management.

section.text: This subtitle only applies to the appointing authorities of units whose employees are governed by the State Personnel Management System laws.

subsection.text: An appointing authority shall take any personnel action governed by Division I of this article consistent with the provisions of Division I and the regulations, guidelines, policies, and procedures adopted under it.
An appointing authority shall cooperate with the Secretary to ensure that Division I of this article is properly enforced.

section.text: An appointing authority may appoint an employee to a position in the skilled service, professional service, management service, or executive service only if the position has been assigned to a class in accordance with Title 4, Subtitle 2 of this article.
Except to the extent otherwise provided by law, the following positions in State government are excluded from the State Personnel Management System:

paragraph.text: a position to which an individual is elected by popular vote; and
a position to which an individual's election or appointment is provided for by the Maryland Constitution.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this subsection or otherwise by law, all positions in the Executive Branch of State government are in the State Personnel Management System.

Except to the extent otherwise provided by law, all positions in a unit in the Executive Branch of State government with an independent personnel system are excluded from the State Personnel Management System.

section.text: All positions in the Judicial Branch of State government are excluded from the State Personnel Management System except as otherwise provided by law.
All positions in the Legislative Branch of State government are excluded from the State Personnel Management System.

The State Personnel Management System includes any other position that is specified by law to be in the skilled service, professional service, management service, executive service, or otherwise in the State Personnel Management System.

Any individual 70 years old or older is eligible for appointment to any nontemporary position in the State Personnel Management System for which the individual qualifies, and the appointment is subject to the provisions of this article.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this title or otherwise by law, all positions in the Executive Branch of State government that are included in the State Personnel Management System are in the skilled service.
The skilled service includes any other position that is specified by law to be in the skilled service.
Except as otherwise provided by law, a position in the Executive Branch of State government is in the professional service if the position:

paragraph.text: requires knowledge of an advanced type in a field of science or learning customarily acquired by a course of specialized intellectual instruction and study; and
normally requires a professional license, advanced degree, or both.

subsection.text: The professional service includes any other position that is determined by the Secretary to be in the professional service.
Except as otherwise provided by law, a position in the Executive Branch of State government is in the management service if the position:

paragraph.text: primarily involves direct responsibility for the oversight and management of personnel and financial resources;
requires the exercise of discretion and independent judgment; and
is not in the executive service.

subsection.text: The management service includes any other position that is determined by the Secretary to be in the management service.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the following positions in the Executive Branch of State government are in the executive service:

paragraph.text: the chief administrator of a principal unit or a comparable position that is not excluded from the State Personnel Management System under § 6-301 of this title as a constitutional or elected office; and
a deputy secretary or assistant secretary of a principal unit or a position that the Secretary determines has similar stature.

subsection.text: The executive service includes any other position that is determined by the Secretary to be in the executive service.
Except as otherwise provided by law, individuals in the following positions in the skilled service and professional service are considered special appointments:

paragraph.text: a position to which an individual is directly appointed by the Governor by an appointment that is not provided for by the Maryland Constitution;
a position to which an individual is directly appointed by the Board of Public Works;
as determined by the Secretary, a position which performs a significant policy role or provides direct support to a member of the executive service;
a position that is assigned to the Government House;
a position that is assigned to the Governor’s Office; and
any other position that is specified by law to be a special appointment.

subsection.text: Except as provided under § 6–105(a) of the State Government Article, a position that is a special appointment may be filled with regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion if the Secretary determines that the position:

paragraph.text: relates to political interests or concerns so as to warrant that political affiliation be a requirement for the position; and

subparagraph.text: requires the provision of meaningful direct or indirect input into the policy–making process; or
provides access to confidential information and:

sub-subparagraph.text: requires substantial intervention or collaboration in the formulation of public policy; or
requires the provision of direct advice or the rendering of direct services to an appointing authority.

paragraph.text: A contractual employee is a temporary employee whose employment is governed by Title 13 of this article.
An emergency employee is a temporary employee who is appointed under § 7-301 of this article.

subsection.text: A temporary employee:

paragraph.text: is not included in the skilled service, professional service, management service, or executive service; and
is not a special appointment described in § 6-405 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, this title applies to all employees in the State Personnel Management System.
This subtitle does not apply to a temporary employee.

paragraph.text: Each employee in the skilled service, professional service, and management service, including special appointments in each classification of each of those services, shall be provided with a written position description which describes the essential duties and responsibilities the employee is expected to perform and the standards for satisfactory performance on a form approved by the Secretary.

A successful applicant for a position in the skilled service, professional service, or management service shall be provided with a position description for review before accepting appointment to the position.

subsection.text: The appointing authority or designee shall approve position descriptions and revised position descriptions for the positions in the unit.

paragraph.text: A supervisor shall:

subparagraph.text: ensure the preparation of a position description for each position over which the supervisor has primary direct responsibility;
maintain position descriptions for the positions under the supervisor’s jurisdiction; and
give each supervised employee a copy of the position description for the employee’s position.

paragraph.text: The supervisor and employee shall review the position description for the employee’s position and make any necessary revision:

subparagraph.text: whenever there is a change in the essential functions of the position; and
as part of the employee’s performance appraisal.

paragraph.text: When there is no position description for a new or vacant position, the primary direct supervisor of the position shall:

subparagraph.text: prepare a position description for the position; and
submit it as part of the selection plan to fill the position.

subsection.text: A position description shall contain information required by the Secretary, including a description of the essential functions of the position.

paragraph.text: The duties and responsibilities assigned to a position shall be consistent with the duties and responsibilities for the position’s assigned class.
An employee may grieve the assignment of duties and responsibilities only if those assigned duties and responsibilities clearly are applicable to a different class.

subsection.text: In this section, “Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.

paragraph.text: An appointing authority may request a State and national criminal history records check from the Central Repository for:

subparagraph.text: a person who is selected for a position in the State Personnel Management System; or
a current employee who is eligible and is being recommended for transfer, promotion, or reassignment to a position in the State Personnel Management System.

paragraph.text: The appointing authority shall apply to the Central Repository for a State and national criminal history records check for each prospective or current employee for whom a records check is sought under paragraph (1) of this subsection.
As part of the application for a criminal history records check, the appointing authority shall submit to the Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: two complete sets of the prospective or current employee’s legible fingerprints taken in a format approved by the Director of the Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
the fee authorized under § 10–221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to criminal history record information; and
the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check.

paragraph.text: In accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Central Repository shall forward to the prospective or current employee and the appointing authority the prospective or current employee’s criminal history record information.
Information obtained from the Central Repository under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: is confidential and may not be redisseminated; and
may be used only for employment purposes authorized under Division I of this article.

subsection.text: A person who is the subject of a criminal history records check under this section may contest the contents of the printed statement issued by the Central Repository as provided in § 10–223 of the Criminal Procedure Article.
The Secretary may adopt regulations, guidelines, and policies to carry out this section.

paragraph.text: This subtitle does not apply to a special appointment position in the skilled service or professional service.

subparagraph.text: This subtitle does not apply to the recruitment for or the appointment to a position in the skilled service or professional service if the appointing authority:

sub-subparagraph.text: decides to recruit for the position under § 7–203(2) of this subtitle;
demonstrates that the position, based on the position description, is difficult to fill;
demonstrates that the recruitment must occur in a timely manner; and
notifies the Department of the recruitment.

subparagraph.text: A recruitment and appointment under this paragraph shall occur in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department.

sub-subparagraph.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to implement this paragraph.

The regulations adopted under this subparagraph shall provide, at a minimum, that for positions designated as special appointments on January 1, 2009, an appointing authority shall retain the same recruitment authority that the appointing authority possessed on January 1, 2009.

subsection.text: Each unit shall fill vacant skilled service and professional service positions in accordance with a position selection plan.
To ensure compliance with State and federal employment laws and to ensure consistency in recruitment and hiring practices in the State Personnel Management System, the Department shall:

paragraph.text: assist units in developing application forms, position selection plans, selection tests, and announcement forms; and
review and audit recruitment and hiring practices of all appointing authorities at least once every 3 years.

subsection.text: On request of a unit that is not able to conduct all or part of its own recruitment or selection testing for a position because it lacks the appropriate resources, the Department, consistent with its resources, shall assist the unit in conducting the requested recruitment and selection testing.
When a skilled service or professional service position is to be filled, the unit shall complete a position selection plan for the position.
A position selection plan shall contain the information about the position that the Secretary requires, including:

paragraph.text: a position description described in § 7-102 of this title;
the minimum qualifications for the class of the position and any selective qualifications required for appointment to the position;
any limitations on selection for the position, including those that limit consideration to:

subparagraph.text: current State or unit employees;
promotional candidates; or
candidates indicating a willingness to work in a location; and

paragraph.text: if applicants for the position are to be recruited, the:

subparagraph.text: location for submitting applications;
manner for posting the position announcement in the unit;
method and length of time for advertising the position;
closing date to receive applications for the position;
plan of development of any selection test to be administered to qualified applicants; and
duration of the list of eligibles that results from the recruitment.

subsection.text: The appointing authority shall:

paragraph.text: approve or disapprove each position selection plan;
authorize funding for approved plans; and
send a copy of an approved selection plan to the equal employment opportunity officer of the unit.

section.text: An appointing authority may select candidates for a position:

paragraph.text: from an existing list of eligible candidates;
if the appointing authority decides to recruit for the position, by recruitment; or

from a special list of eligible candidates whom the Division of Rehabilitation Services of the Department of Education certifies as being physically capable and adequately trained to qualify for the position.

subsection.text: To recruit candidates for a position, an appointing authority shall prepare a job announcement for the position and conduct recruitment in accordance with the position selection plan.
A job announcement shall contain:

paragraph.text: a summary of the position description;
the minimum qualifications for the class and any selective qualifications necessary for consideration;
the type of selection test that will be administered to those meeting the position's minimum qualifications;
the location and deadline for submitting applications; and
the duration of the list of eligibles derived from the announcement.

subsection.text: For a vacant position under this subtitle, the appointing authority shall:

paragraph.text: send a copy of the selection plan and job announcement to the Secretary at least 1 week before posting the job announcement to assure public access;
if current employees in the unit may be eligible for the position:

subparagraph.text: post the job announcement for at least 2 weeks before the deadline for submitting applications, in at least one centralized location in that unit that is accessible to all employees; and
use any other method reasonably calculated to give eligible employees notice of the vacancy; and

paragraph.text: advertise the position vacancy at least 2 weeks before the deadline for submitting applications by:

subparagraph.text: making available a job announcement to all appropriate State agencies, based on selection limitations; and

using any other method that is reasonably calculated to ensure a sufficient pool of applicants, including printed advertisements in newspapers and journals, paper and electronic bulletin board postings, and special notices.

subsection.text: After the close of a position announcement, the appointing authority shall:

paragraph.text: review the applications received to determine the applicants who meet the minimum qualifications for the position;
prepare a register of qualified applicants in random order;
send to unqualified applicants a notice that they have failed to meet the minimum qualifications for the position; and

except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, if a competitive examination that requires attendance at a test site is required for the position, send a notice of the examination to qualified applicants on the register at least 10 days before the test administration date.

subsection.text: If less than ten but more than two applicants meet the minimum requirements for a position, the appointing authority may:

paragraph.text: make a selection from the register without the need for further selection testing; or
readvertise the position vacancy.
An appointing authority may use any appropriate selection process to rate qualified applicants.
A unit must be able to establish the job relatedness, reliability, and validity of the selection tests that it uses.
A selection test must be:

subparagraph.text: free of charge; and
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, open to all qualified applicants.

paragraph.text: An appointing authority:

subparagraph.text: may disqualify and refuse to examine an otherwise qualified applicant who intentionally falsifies information in the application; and
shall give the applicant a written notice of the reason for the proposed disqualification.

paragraph.text: An applicant who is disqualified under this subsection may submit a written response to the notice.

subsection.text: A credit under this section shall be applied to an applicant’s score on any selection test administered to establish placement on a list of eligible candidates for which the applicant otherwise is qualified and has at least the minimum passing score on a selection test.

For a current State employee, an appointing authority shall apply a credit on a selection test, of one-quarter point for each year of service in State government, up to a maximum of five points for 20 years of State service.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “eligible veteran” means a veteran of any branch of the armed forces of the United States who has received an honorable discharge or a certificate of satisfactory completion of military service, including the National Guard and the military reserves.

subparagraph.text: An appointing authority shall apply a credit of ten points on any selection test for:

sub-subparagraph.text: an eligible veteran;
the spouse of an eligible veteran who has a service connected disability; or
the surviving spouse of a deceased eligible veteran.

subparagraph.text: An appointing authority shall apply a credit of two additional points on any selection test for:

sub-subparagraph.text: an eligible veteran who has a service connected disability; or
a former prisoner of war.

paragraph.text: The following applicants are ineligible for a credit under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: a current State employee; and
an eligible veteran who is convicted of a crime after being discharged from or completing military service.
In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Host county” means any county in which a qualified prison facility is located.
“Adjacent county” means any county adjacent to a host county.

“Qualified prison facility” means any new State correctional institution of 750 beds or more constructed for the Division of Correction of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services on or after January 1, 1985.

paragraph.text: In the selection process for an initial appointment to any position in a qualified prison facility, an appointing authority shall allow five points to each resident of the host county or an adjacent county if, in the most recent 12-month period for which data is available as reported by the Maryland Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, that county had an average unemployment rate that is more than 1.5 times the State unemployment rate as a whole.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Adjacent district” means a legislative district within Baltimore City adjacent to the host district or, if the adjacent district extends beyond Baltimore City, that part of the district within Baltimore City.
“Host district” means the legislative district in which the Baltimore City Juvenile Justice Center is located.
