subparagraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a death benefit in the amount of $100,000 shall be paid to the surviving spouse, children, or dependent parents of any employee subject to this section who is killed in the performance of duties on or after July 1, 2000.
A death benefit may not be paid under this paragraph if an employee is killed as a result of the employee’s negligence.

A death benefit may not be paid under this paragraph if a member of the Maryland National Guard who is killed in the performance of duties is eligible to receive dependency and indemnity compensation under rules prescribed by the United States Department of Veterans Affairs.

A death benefit in the amount of $50,000 shall be paid to the surviving spouse, children, or dependent parents of any State employee covered by the provisions of § 1-202 of the Public Safety Article who is killed in the performance of duties on or after July 1, 2000.
A death benefit may not be paid under this paragraph if an employee is killed as a result of the employee’s negligence.
An individual who receives a death benefit under this paragraph may not also receive a death benefit under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: A death benefit under this section shall be in addition to any:

subparagraph.text: workers’ compensation benefits;
proceeds of any form of life insurance, regardless of who paid the premiums on the insurance;
benefit provided to a State employee covered by the provisions of § 1-202 of the Public Safety Article; and

except as provided in paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection, benefits paid to a member of the Maryland National Guard, the member’s estate, or the member’s beneficiaries or survivors by the United States.

paragraph.text: On notification by the head of the unit that employed the decedent, the Secretary shall determine whether a death benefit will be paid under this section.
If the Secretary determines that a death benefit is payable, payment shall be made:

subparagraph.text: to the surviving spouse;
if there is no surviving spouse, to the surviving children, in equal shares; or
if there is no surviving spouse or children, to the surviving parent or parents, if the parent was a dependent as defined in § 152 of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: A death benefit under this section shall be paid out of funds which the Governor may appropriate for that purpose in the State budget.
A decision of the Secretary under this section:

paragraph.text: is the final administrative decision; and
is not subject to appeal under Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

section.text: In this title, “employee” includes a former State employee.
This subtitle applies to all employees in the State Personnel Management System within the Executive Branch except temporary employees.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided, the appointing authority has the burden of proof by a preponderance of the evidence in any proceeding under this subtitle. The head of a principal unit, the Secretary, and the Office of Administrative Hearings shall apply that standard of proof in appeals under this subtitle.

After taking a disciplinary action against an employee, an appointing authority may not impose an additional disciplinary action against that employee for the same conduct unless additional information is made known to the appointing authority after the disciplinary action was taken.

The suspension of an employee who is exempt from the overtime pay requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act, and under any changes to the Fair Labor Standards Act, shall be done so that the employee's overtime exemption will not be lost.
An employee may choose any person to assist or represent the employee during an appeal under this subtitle and shall notify the employer of that choice.

section.text: An appointing authority may take the following disciplinary actions against any employee:

paragraph.text: give the employee a written reprimand;
direct the forfeiture of up to 15 work days of the employee’s accrued annual leave;
suspend the employee without pay;
deny the employee an annual pay increase;
demote the employee to a lower pay grade; or
with prior approval of the head of the principal unit:

subparagraph.text: terminate the employee’s employment, without prejudice; or

if the appointing authority finds that the employee’s actions are egregious to the extent that the employee does not merit employment in any capacity with the State, terminate the employee’s employment, with prejudice.

section.text: The following actions are causes for automatic termination of employment:

paragraph.text: intentional conduct, without justification, that:

subparagraph.text: seriously injures another person;
causes substantial damage to property; or
seriously threatens the safety of the workplace;

paragraph.text: theft of State property of a value greater than $300;
illegal sale, use, or possession of drugs on the job;
conviction of a controlled dangerous substance offense by an employee in a designated sensitive classification;
conviction of a felony;

accepting for personal use any fee, gift, or other valuable thing in connection with or during the course of State employment if given to the employee by any person with the hope or expectation of receiving a favor or better treatment than that accorded to other persons;

subparagraph.text: violation of the Fair Election Practices Act; or
using, threatening, or attempting to use political influence or the influence of any State employee or officer in securing promotion, transfer, leave of absence, or increased pay;

paragraph.text: wantonly careless conduct or unwarrantable excessive force in the treatment or care of an individual who is a client, patient, prisoner, or any other individual who is in the care or custody of this State; and
violation of § 3–314 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: Before taking any disciplinary action related to employee misconduct, an appointing authority shall:

paragraph.text: investigate the alleged misconduct;
meet with the employee;
consider any mitigating circumstances;
determine the appropriate disciplinary action, if any, to be imposed; and
give the employee a written notice of the disciplinary action to be taken and the employee’s appeal rights.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, an appointing authority may impose any disciplinary action no later than 30 days after the appointing authority acquires knowledge of the misconduct for which the disciplinary action is imposed.

paragraph.text: An appointing authority may suspend an employee without pay no later than 5 workdays following the close of the employee's next shift after the appointing authority acquires knowledge of the misconduct for which the suspension is imposed.
Saturdays, Sundays, legal holidays, and employee leave days are excluded in calculating the 5-workday period under this subsection.
Issuing a counseling memorandum is an instructional communication and is not a disciplinary action within the meaning of this subtitle.

Within 5 days after receiving a counseling memorandum, an employee may submit to the employee's appointing authority a written response to the memorandum. The response shall be placed in the employee's file and attached to any record of the memorandum.
An employee may not take any other action in response to a counseling memorandum.
Placing an employee on leave without pay when the employee is absent without approval is not a disciplinary action within the meaning of this subtitle.
An employee who is placed on leave without pay for an unapproved absence also may be subject to disciplinary action for the unapproved absence.
Requiring an employee to make restitution to the State for loss or damage to State property due to the employee's negligence is not a disciplinary action within the meaning of this subtitle.
An appointing authority may not require an employee to pay restitution exceeding 3% of the employee's annual base pay.
An employee who is ordered to make restitution under this subsection also may be subject to civil prosecution or criminal prosecution for wanton destruction of property under the State law.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not preclude an appointing authority and an employee from agreeing to the:

paragraph.text: holding in abeyance of a disciplinary action for a period not to exceed 18 months in order to permit an employee to improve conduct or performance; or
imposition of a lesser disciplinary action as a final and binding action, not subject to any further review.
If an employee fails to appeal a decision in accordance with this subtitle, the employee is considered to have accepted the decision.
A failure to decide an appeal in accordance with this subtitle is considered a denial from which an appeal may be made.

subsection.text: The parties may agree to waive or extend any time stated in this subtitle.
Each party shall make every effort to resolve an appeal at the lowest level possible.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, this section applies only to employees in the skilled service or the professional service.
This section does not apply to an employee under a special appointment described in § 6-405 of this article.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, an employee in the skilled service or the professional service may appeal a disciplinary action taken while the employee is on probation only on the basis that the action was illegal or unconstitutional.
The employee has the burden of proof in an appeal under this subsection.
The limitations in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection do not apply to an employee in the skilled service or the professional service who is on probation following a promotion or reinstatement.

An employee or an employee’s representative may file with the head of the principal unit a written appeal of a disciplinary action that states, to the extent possible, the issues of fact and law that the employee believes would warrant rescinding the disciplinary action.
An appeal under this subtitle must be filed within 15 days after the employee receives notice of the appointing authority’s action.

subsection.text: The head of the principal unit may confer with the employee before making a decision.

paragraph.text: The head of the principal unit may:

subparagraph.text: uphold the disciplinary action; or
rescind or modify the disciplinary action taken and restore to the employee any lost time, compensation, status, or benefits.

paragraph.text: Within 15 days after receiving an appeal, the head of the principal unit shall issue to the employee a written decision that addresses each point raised in the appeal.

subsection.text: Within 15 days after issuance of a decision to rescind a disciplinary action, the disciplinary action shall be expunged from the employee’s personnel records.

paragraph.text: Within 10 days after receiving a decision under § 11–109 of this subtitle, an employee or an employee’s representative may appeal the decision in writing to the Secretary.
An appeal shall state, to the extent possible, the issues of fact and law that are the basis for the appeal.

subsection.text: Within 30 days after receiving an appeal, the Secretary or designee shall:

subparagraph.text: mediate a settlement between the employee and the unit; or
refer the appeal to the Office of Administrative Hearings; and

paragraph.text: advise the employee in writing of the Secretary’s action.
Within 30 days after receiving the appeal, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall schedule a hearing and notify the parties of the hearing date.

The Office of Administrative Hearings shall dispose of the appeal or conduct a hearing on each appeal in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article. The Office is bound by any regulation, declaratory ruling, prior adjudication, or other settled, preexisting policy, to the same extent as the Department is or would have been bound if it were hearing the case.
Except as otherwise provided by this subtitle, the Office of Administrative Hearings may:

subparagraph.text: uphold the disciplinary action;
rescind or modify the disciplinary action taken and restore to the employee any lost time, compensation, status, or benefits; or
order:

sub-subparagraph.text: reinstatement to the position that the employee held at dismissal;
full back pay and benefits; or
both 1 and 2.

paragraph.text: Within 45 days after the close of the hearing record, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall issue to the parties a written decision.
The decision of the Office of Administrative Hearings is the final administrative decision.
The principal unit that employs the employee shall pay all costs related to the appeal that are incurred by the Office of Administrative Hearings.

If a written decision issued under subsection (d) of this section is not appealed in accordance with § 10–222 of the State Government Article, within 45 days after issuance of a decision to rescind a disciplinary action, the disciplinary action shall be expunged from the employee’s personnel records.

If a written decision issued under subsection (d) of this section is appealed in accordance with § 10–222 of the State Government Article, within 45 days after the issuance of a final decision on appeal to rescind a disciplinary action, the disciplinary action shall be expunged from the employee’s personnel records.

section.text: The Secretary, by regulation, shall establish policies and procedures for disciplinary actions related to employee performance, that include procedures for:

paragraph.text: providing counseling to an employee with deficiencies in performance;
allowing an employee the opportunity to improve deficiencies in performance;
imposing disciplinary actions, if warranted; and
providing notice to an employee of any disciplinary action and the employee’s appeal rights.

subsection.text: If the principal unit has established a peer review panel for disciplinary actions in accordance with regulations adopted by the Secretary, the employee and the principal unit may agree in writing to submit the appeal to the peer review panel, instead of using the appeal procedures in §§ 11-109 and 11-110 of this subtitle.
The peer review panel may take action as set forth in § 11-110(d)(1).

paragraph.text: Within the time required by regulation, the peer review panel shall issue to the parties a written decision.
The decision of the peer review panel is the final administrative decision.

If a written decision issued under subsection (c) of this section is not appealed in accordance with § 10-222 of the State Government Article, within 45 days after issuance of a decision to rescind a disciplinary action, the disciplinary action shall be expunged from the employee’s personnel records.

If a written decision issued under subsection (c) of this section is appealed in accordance with § 10-222 of the State Government Article, within 45 days after the issuance of a final decision on appeal to rescind a disciplinary action, the disciplinary action shall be expunged from the employee’s personnel records.

subsection.text: This section only applies to an employee:

paragraph.text: in the management service;
in executive service; or
under a special appointment described in § 6-405 of this article.
An employee or an employee’s representative may file a written appeal of a disciplinary action with the head of the principal unit.
An appeal:

subparagraph.text: must be filed within 15 days after the employee receives notice of the disciplinary action; and
may only be based on the grounds that the disciplinary action is illegal or unconstitutional.

paragraph.text: The employee has the burden of proof in an appeal under this section.

subsection.text: The head of the principal unit may confer with the employee before making a decision.

paragraph.text: The head of the principal unit may:

subparagraph.text: uphold the disciplinary action; or
rescind or modify the disciplinary action and restore to the employee any lost time, compensation, status, or benefits.

paragraph.text: Within 15 days after receiving an appeal, the head of the principal unit shall issue the employee a written decision.
The decision of the head of the principal unit is the final administrative decision.

subsection.text: Within 15 days after issuance of a decision to rescind a disciplinary action, the disciplinary action shall be expunged from the employee’s personnel records.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, this subtitle only applies to skilled service and professional service employees in the State Personnel Management System.
The procedures in this subtitle do not apply to:

subparagraph.text: a disciplinary action under Subtitle 1 of this title;
a termination or separation from employment under Subtitle 3 of this title; or
special appointees.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not prevent the layoff of an employee who submits to the head of the employee's principal unit a written request to be laid off.

section.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations to provide procedures that are uniform among the principal units for:

paragraph.text: the layoff of employees in the skilled service or the professional service; and
the reinstatement of laid-off and separated skilled service or professional service employees to comparable positions in State employment.

section.text: An employee shall be laid off if the employee is in a position that will be abolished, discontinued, or vacated because of a change in organization or because of a stoppage or lack of work.
At least 60 days before a layoff is effective, an appointing authority shall give a notice of a layoff to each employee to be affected by the layoff.

subsection.text: For purposes of a layoff, an appointing authority shall compute the total number of seniority points for each employee subject to the layoff as follows:

paragraph.text: one point for each month of State employment;
one point for each month of employment in the principal unit in which the layoff will occur;
one point for each month of employment in the job series in which the layoff will occur;
ten points for an eligible veteran; and
two points for an eligible veteran who has a service–connected disability or is a former prisoner of war.

subsection.text: An employee’s seniority points are the total of the points determined under subsection (a) of this section.
In this section, “eligible veteran” has the meaning stated in § 7–207(c) of this article.
An eligible veteran who is convicted of a crime after being discharged from or completing military service is ineligible for a credit under this section.
Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section:

paragraph.text: employees in a class are to be laid off based on seniority points; and
the employee in the class with less seniority points shall be laid off before others in the class with higher seniority points.

subsection.text: If two or more employees in the same class have an equal number of seniority points, the employee with less points for total State employment shall be laid off first.
If two or more employees in the same class have an equal number of seniority points and the same number of points for total State employment, the appointing authority shall:

paragraph.text: determine which employee to retain by making a written evaluation of the skills, knowledge, or abilities of each employee; and
submit the evaluation to the Secretary.

subsection.text: An employee being laid off may displace another employee who has the least seniority points:

paragraph.text: in the same class or job series as the employee being laid off; or
in any other class in which the laid-off employee previously held satisfactory nonprobationary status within the 36 months immediately prior to the effective date of the layoff.

subsection.text: Subsection (a) of this section shall apply:

paragraph.text: first to the employee’s current appointing authority regardless of geographical area;
if the provisions in paragraph (1) of this subsection are not available, to the employee’s current principal unit; or
a secretary or head of a State principal unit may limit the displacement within the principal unit to one or more of the established geographical areas as prescribed by the Secretary.

subsection.text: The employee with the most seniority points shall be the first employee to be reinstated in the class from which the employee was laid off or from which the employee was separated under § 11-302 of this title or to any lower class in the same job series within the principal department or other independent unit in which the layoff or separation under § 11-302 of this title occurred.

Reinstatement to a comparable class to which the Secretary has certified employees who were laid-off or who were separated under § 11-302 of this title shall be made from among the five laid-off or separated employees with the most seniority points who are certified to the class.

section.text: This subtitle applies to all nontemporary employees in the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: An employee is separated from State service when the appropriation in the State budget for the position is:

paragraph.text: omitted by the Governor, as evidenced in the supporting documentation submitted with the budget;
struck by the General Assembly, as evidenced in the budget bill or in the report of the budget committees; or
reduced by the Governor in accordance with § 7-213 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, as evidenced in the supporting documentation submitted to the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: An employee may not appeal a separation from employment under this section.

An employee who is separated under this section is not subject to the layoff provisions of Subtitle 2 of this title with the exception that an employee who is separated shall have the same reinstatement rights as a laid-off employee.
An appointing authority may terminate the employment of a probationary employee.
Before terminating an employee who is on probation, the appointing authority shall give the employee a notice of termination at least 10 days before the effective date of the termination.
An appointing authority may suspend a probationary employee with pay between the date of the notice and the effective date of the termination.
A probationary employee may appeal a termination under this section only on the grounds that the termination is illegal or unconstitutional.

paragraph.text: This section applies to employees on probation following a promotion or reinstatement to a position in the skilled service or professional service.
This section does not apply to probationary employees in the management service.

subsection.text: If, in the appointing authority's judgment, a probationary employee subject to this section is unable or unwilling to satisfactorily perform the duties or responsibilities of the position, the appointing authority shall:

paragraph.text: return the employee to the employee's former position if it is vacant; or
demote the employee to a position comparable to the employee’s position within the appointing authority's jurisdiction.

subsection.text: A probationary employee may appeal a demotion under this section as a disciplinary action.
This section only applies to an employee who is in a position:

paragraph.text: under a special appointment;
in the management service; or
in the executive service.

subsection.text: Each employee subject to this section:

paragraph.text: serves at the pleasure of the employee’s appointing authority; and
may be terminated from employment for any reason that is not illegal or unconstitutional, solely in the discretion of the appointing authority.

subsection.text: A management service employee or a special appointment employee designated by the Secretary under § 4–201(c)(2)(i) of this article may not be terminated for the purpose of creating a new position for another individual’s appointment because of that individual’s political affiliation, belief, or opinion.
An employee or an employee’s representative may file a written appeal of an employment termination under this section as described under § 11–113 of this title.

section.text: As of the effective date of an employment termination, the individual whose employment is terminated:

paragraph.text: is a former employee; and
shall have the appeal rights provided by this title.

section.text: Any employee may terminate employment by resigning from the employee's position.
Any resignation from a position in the skilled service or professional service is void if the resignation, whether dated or undated, is signed before the day of appointment to that position.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Employer” means one or more of the following:

paragraph.text: an employee's appointing authority;
an employee's principal unit; or
the Department of Budget and Management.
“Grievance” means a dispute between an employee and the employee’s employer about the interpretation of and application to the employee of:

subparagraph.text: a personnel policy or regulation adopted by the Secretary; or
any other policy or regulation over which management has control.

paragraph.text: “Grievance” does not include a dispute about:

subparagraph.text: a pay grade or range for a class;
the amount or the effective date of a statewide pay increase;
the establishment of a class;
the assignment of a class to a service category;
the establishment of classification standards;
a mid–year performance appraisal; or
an oral reprimand or counseling.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, this title applies to all employees in the State Personnel Management System within the Executive Branch.
This title does not apply to:

paragraph.text: an employee who is appointed by the Governor whose appointment requires the Governor's approval;
an employee in the executive service of the State Personnel Management System;
a temporary employee;
an attorney in the Office of the Attorney General or the Office of the Public Defender;
a State Police officer;
an employee who is subject to a collective bargaining agreement that contains another grievance procedure;
an employee, including a member of a faculty, who is subject to a contract or regulation governing teacher tenure;
a member of the faculty, an officer, or an administrative employee of Baltimore City Community College;
a student employee;
an individual who, as an inmate or patient in an institution, is employed by the State; or
an administrative law judge in the Office of Administrative Hearings.

subsection.text: An employee with a grievance or the grievant's representative may present the grievance free from coercion, discrimination, interference, reprisal, or restraint.

Unless another procedure is provided for by this article, the grievance procedure is the exclusive remedy through which a nontemporary employee in the State Personnel Management System may seek an administrative remedy for violations of the provisions of this article.

section.text: For employees of the Department, the Secretary shall provide separate grievance procedures that are similar to the grievance procedures specified in this title.

subsection.text: A grievant may choose any person to assist or represent the grievant at any time during the grievance process and shall notify the employer of that choice.

The appointing authority, the head of the principal unit, or the Secretary may designate an individual to assist or represent them at any step of the grievance process and shall notify the grievant of that designation.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, if a grievant fails to appeal a decision in accordance with this title to the next step in the grievance procedure, the grievant is considered to have accepted the decision.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, a failure to decide a grievance at any step in the grievance procedure in accordance with this title is considered a denial from which an appeal may be made.
The parties may agree to waive any time limitations specified in this title.

If the individual responsible to prepare a decision to a grievance at Step One or Step Two of the grievance procedure cannot respond within the time specified in this title because the individual is on approved leave for 3 or more days:

paragraph.text: the period for the decision shall be extended by the number of days of the approved leave, up to a maximum of 14 days; and
the grievant shall be notified of the extension of time.

section.text: The Secretary shall provide for forms for initiating and processing grievances.
Each party to a grievance shall make every effort to resolve the grievance at the lowest level possible.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the three steps available to a grievant in the grievance procedure are:

subparagraph.text: Step One: the initiation of a grievance procedure;
Step Two: an appeal to the head of the principal unit; and
Step Three: an appeal to the Secretary.

paragraph.text: If a grievance is based on a performance rating of satisfactory or better:

subparagraph.text: the grievant only may appeal the grievance at Steps One and Two of the grievance procedure; and
a decision at Step Two of the grievance procedure is final.

paragraph.text: When a grievant's appointing authority is also the head of the principal unit, the grievant shall appeal the Step One decision directly to Step Three of the grievance procedure.
If the basis of a grievance is an action taken by the principal unit or by the Department, the parties may agree to proceed to Step Two or Step Three of the grievance procedure as appropriate.

section.text: Before initiating a grievance procedure, an employee shall present the matter orally to the employee's supervisor for informal discussion.

subsection.text: A grievant may initiate a grievance proceeding by filing a written grievance with the grievant's appointing authority. The grievant shall provide a copy of the grievance to the grievant's supervisor when the grievance is filed.
A grievance procedure must be initiated by an employee within 20 days after:

paragraph.text: the occurrence of the alleged act that is the basis of the grievance; or
the employee first knew of or reasonably should have known of the alleged act that is the basis of the grievance.

subsection.text: Within 10 days after receiving a grievance, the appointing authority shall hold a conference with the grievant and they shall attempt to resolve the grievance.
Within 10 days after the conference, the appointing authority shall issue a written decision to the grievant and may grant any appropriate remedy under § 12-402(a) of this title.

paragraph.text: Within 10 days after receiving a decision under § 12-203 of this subtitle, a grievant or a grievant's representative may appeal the decision in writing to the head of the grievant’s principal unit or designee.
An appeal shall include a copy of the decision being appealed.

subsection.text: Within 10 days after receiving an appeal, the head of the principal unit or designee shall:

paragraph.text: review the grievance record; and
confer with the grievant and they shall attempt to resolve the grievance.

subsection.text: Within 10 days after the conference, the head of the principal unit or designee shall issue a written decision to the grievant and may grant any appropriate remedy under § 12-402(a) of this title.

paragraph.text: Within 10 days after receiving a decision under § 12-204 of this subtitle, a grievant or a grievant’s representative may appeal the decision in writing to the Secretary.
An appeal shall include a copy of the decision being appealed and any prior decisions.
Within 30 days after an appeal is received, the Secretary or designee shall:

subparagraph.text: review the grievance record;
if the grievance is based on a position reclassification, order an audit of the position if it has not been audited within the last year; and
take the action described in paragraph (2) of this subsection and give the parties written notice of that action.
If the Secretary or designee does not concur with the decision of the unit, the Secretary or designee shall attempt to resolve the grievance with a settlement that is binding on all parties.
The Secretary or designee shall determine whether the principal unit that employs the grievant will accept a settlement.
If the grievance is not settled, the Secretary or designee shall refer the grievance to the Office of Administrative Hearings.

The Office of Administrative Hearings shall dispose of the grievance or conduct a hearing on each grievance received from the Secretary in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

The Office is bound by any regulation, declaratory ruling, prior adjudication, or other settled, preexisting policy, to the same extent as the Department is or would have been bound if it were hearing the case.
The employee has the burden of proof by a preponderance of the evidence.

Within 45 days after the close of the hearing record, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall issue a written decision to the parties and may grant any appropriate remedy under § 12-402 of this title.
The decision of the Office of Administrative Hearings is the final administrative decision.

paragraph.text: Any costs the Office of Administrative Hearings incurs for the appeal of a grievance to the Office of Administrative Hearings shall be paid by the principal unit that employs the grievant.

section.text: If a grievant's principal unit has established a peer review panel for grievances in accordance with regulations adopted by the Secretary, the grievant may elect to:

paragraph.text: waive Step Two and Step Three of the grievance procedure; and
submit the grievance to the peer review panel after Step One of the grievance procedure.

section.text: The peer review panel shall review each grievance submitted to it in accordance with established procedures.

subsection.text: After a review, the panel shall issue a written decision to the parties and may grant any appropriate remedy under § 12-402(a) of this title.
The decision of the peer review panel is the final administrative decision.

section.text: A decision maker at any step in the grievance procedure shall determine the:

paragraph.text: proper interpretation or application of the policy, procedure, or regulation involved in the grievance; and
appropriate remedy.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the remedies available to a grievant under this title are limited to the restoration of the rights, pay, status, or benefits that the grievant otherwise would have had if the contested policy, procedure, or regulation had been applied appropriately as determined by the final decision maker.

paragraph.text: A decision maker at Step Two or Step Three of the grievance procedure may order an appointing authority to grant back pay.

subparagraph.text: In a reclassification grievance back pay may be awarded for a period not exceeding 1 year before the grievance procedure was initiated.
A back pay order under this paragraph is in the discretion of the Secretary and the Office of Administrative Hearings.

paragraph.text: Subject to the limitations in Title 14, Subtitle 2 of this article, an appointing authority shall carry out a back pay order issued under this subsection.

section.text: On conclusion of each step of a grievance proceeding, a copy of the grievance and its disposition shall be given to the grievant and the grievant's representative.

subsection.text: An appointing authority, the head of a principal unit, or the Secretary may consolidate multiple grievances filed by one employee and process the grievances in a single proceeding.
If the grievants agree, an appointing authority, the head of a principal unit, or the Secretary may consolidate similar grievances and process the grievances together in a single proceeding.
The Office of Administrative Hearings may consolidate and process in a single proceeding multiple grievances filed by one employee or similar grievances filed by more than one grievant.

A grievant and the grievant's representative shall be given reasonable time during work to investigate and process the grievance and to participate at any conference or hearing relating to the grievance.
An employee shall be granted release time from the employee's normal work schedule to attend a grievance conference or hearing as a witness.

Expenses incurred in connection with attendance by an employee at grievance conferences or hearings, whether as a grievant, as a grievant's representative, or as a witness, shall be borne by that employee's unit.
In this title, “contractual employee” means an individual:

paragraph.text: who, under a written agreement, provides temporary personal services to the State for pay;
who is not employed in a budgeted position; and
who has an employer-employee relationship with the State in which the State:

subparagraph.text: furnishes necessary tools and a place to work;
has the right to control and direct the details, means, and results of the performance of the services; and
has the right to discharge the individual from employment.

subsection.text: “Contractual employee” does not include an individual who is employed as:

paragraph.text: an employee in the:

subparagraph.text: skilled service;
professional service;
management service; or
executive service; or

paragraph.text: an emergency employee.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies to all units in the Executive Branch of State government, except a unit with an independent personnel system.
The Secretary may exempt specific types of contractual employees from the certification and other requirements of this subtitle.

Except as otherwise authorized under § 13-201(b) of this subtitle, a unit may not execute or renew a contract for the employment of a contractual employee unless the Secretary issues to the unit a certification that:

paragraph.text: the employment of the contractual employee is for services that cannot be performed by assignment or hiring of any nontemporary employee;
the rate of pay for the contractual employee is comparable to the rate paid to employees in positions that involve comparable duties, responsibilities, experience, and authority; and
the services to be performed under the contract encompass functions that:

subparagraph.text: are infrequent;
are needed for a limited time;
are unusual; or
need to be implemented quickly and for which there is no reasonable alternative.

subsection.text: The Secretary may issue a certification for any effective period that does not exceed the period of the contract between the unit and the contractual employee.
The Secretary shall adopt guidelines for the recruitment and selection of contractual employees.
These guidelines shall require a contracting unit:

paragraph.text: to make a reasonable effort to publicly solicit applicants for contractual employment;

to make a reasonable effort to screen and select contractual employees by using methods and criteria that are uniformly applied to all applicants for a particular instance of contractual employment; and
to use criteria to select contractual employees that:

subparagraph.text: are based on the qualifications of the applicant; and
conform to subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: All personnel actions concerning a contractual employee shall be made in accordance with § 2-302 of this article.
An action may be taken with regard to age, sex, or disability to the extent that age, sex, or disability involves a bona fide occupational qualification.

subsection.text: To the extent feasible, a unit shall conduct the recruitment and selection of contractual employees according to the guidelines adopted under this section.

section.text: Except as authorized under § 13-303 of this title, the Secretary may not continue certification for any contractual employee if the Secretary determines that the services performed under the contract:

paragraph.text: encompass permanent functions;
have no specific expiration date; and
regularly are performed on a basis that is at least equal to 50% of the work responsibility of a full-time permanent employee.

subsection.text: The Secretary periodically shall audit a sample of instances of contractual employment in the various units to determine whether:

paragraph.text: justification exists in each instance to continue certification for the contractual employee; and
the guidelines adopted under § 13-203 of this subtitle have been followed.
If, as a result of an audit, the Secretary determines that services performed by a contractual employee should be performed by a permanent employee, the Secretary shall:

subparagraph.text: refuse to renew the certification for the contractual employee; and
recommend that a position for a permanent employee be established.

paragraph.text: If, as a result of an audit, the Secretary determines that a unit has not complied with the guidelines adopted under § 13-203 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall:

subparagraph.text: advise the unit of the nature of the noncompliance; and
suggest alternate criteria or methods that would have complied with the guidelines.

section.text: This subtitle applies to all units in the Executive Branch of State government, except a unit with an independent personnel system.
If a contractual position is replaced by a budgeted position, a contractual employee in the contractual position may transfer to the budgeted position, if:

paragraph.text: the employee meets the minimum qualifications for the budgeted position and has at least 6 continuous months of satisfactory service as of the date on which the replacement occurs;
there is a continuing need for the function to be performed;
the agency can document a competitive hiring process; and
the budgeted position replacing the contractual position was not available at the time the contractual employee was hired.

section.text: To enable a contractual employee to participate in any required examination for a budgeted position under this subtitle, the Secretary may certify the continuation of the employee's contract for a maximum period of 1 year after the date on which the budgeted position is created.

subsection.text: A contractual employee who transfers to a budgeted position under this subtitle or who is selected to fill a budgeted position in the State Personnel Management System, without a break in service, in the same principal unit that employs the contractual employee, shall be given credit for service in the contractual position for the purpose of establishing:

paragraph.text: steps in the pay grade applicable to the budgeted position;
annual leave; and
seniority rights.

subsection.text: A contractual employee who transfers to a budgeted position under this subtitle or who is selected to fill a budgeted position shall become a member of the Employees’ Pension System of the State of Maryland.

section.text: This subtitle does not preclude the General Assembly from prohibiting the creation of a budgeted position or the replacement of a contractual position with a budgeted position in the State budget.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Service contract” means a procurement contract for services that:

paragraph.text: will be provided to a unit in the Executive Branch of State government;
will be performed within a State-operated facility; and
in the estimation of the procurement officer, will exceed an annual cost of $100,000.

subsection.text: “Services” has the meaning stated in § 11-101 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
“Unit” has the meaning stated in § 11-101 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.text: The policy of this State is to use State employees to perform all State functions in State-operated facilities in preference to contracting with the private sector to perform those functions.

subsection.text: A service contract may be entered into only as approved by the Board of Public Works in accordance with this subtitle.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the Board of Public Works may approve a service contract for a unit only if the Board receives a certification from the Department that:

paragraph.text: the service contract is exempt under § 13-404(b) of this subtitle; or
the unit has complied with the requirements of § 13-404(c) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If the General Assembly authorizes or requires that certain services be performed by an independent contractor, the Board of Public Works may approve a service contract for those services without the certification required by subsection (b) of this section.
The Department may certify a service contract to the Board of Public Works as provided in this section.
The Department may certify a service contract as being exempt from the preference stated in § 13-402 of this subtitle if:

paragraph.text: State employees are not available to perform the services;
a conflict of interest would result if a State employee were to perform the services;
the nature of the services meets the standards set by the Department for emergency appointments;
the services are incidental to the purchase or lease of personal property or real property, such as a service agreement that is part of the purchase or rental of computers or office equipment; or
a clear need exists to obtain an unbiased finding or opinion, such as an expert witness in litigation.

subsection.text: The Department may certify a service contract that is not exempt under subsection (b) of this section only if:

paragraph.text: the unit that seeks to enter into the service contract has complied with § 13-405 of this subtitle; and
the Department finds that:

subparagraph.text: the potential economic advantage of entering into the service contract is not outweighed by the preference stated in § 13-402 of this subtitle;
the service contract does not adversely affect the affirmative action efforts of this State;
the service contract includes adequate control mechanisms to ensure that the services will be performed in accordance with the service contract; and
the service contract complies with all of the requirements of Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: A unit that seeks to enter into a service contract that is not exempt under § 13–403(c) or § 13–404(b) of this subtitle shall submit to the Department the information required by this section.

The unit shall submit a demonstration that the unit has taken formal and positive steps to consider alternatives to the service contract, including reorganization, reevaluation of service, and reevaluation of performance.

paragraph.text: The unit shall submit calculations that:

subparagraph.text: compare the cost of the service contract with the cost of using State employees; and
show savings to this State, over the duration of the service contract, of 20% of the contract or $200,000, whichever is less.

paragraph.text: In calculating the cost comparison required by this subsection, a unit shall include:

subparagraph.text: direct costs, including fringe benefits;

indirect overhead costs, including the proportional share of existing administrative salaries and benefits, rent, equipment costs, utilities, and materials, but only to the extent that those costs are attributed solely to the service in question and would not exist if the service were not performed by State employees;
any continuing or transitional costs that would be directly associated with contracting for the services, including unemployment compensation and the cost of transitional services; and

additional costs of performance of the services by State employees, including salaries and benefits of additional staff and the cost of additional space, equipment, and materials needed to perform the services.

paragraph.text: The unit shall submit a formal plan of assistance for all State employees who will be adversely affected by the service contract.
The plan of assistance shall include:

subparagraph.text: efforts to place affected employees in vacant positions in the unit or in another unit;
provisions in the service contract, if feasible, for the hiring by the contractor of displaced employees; and
prior notification to affected employees in accordance with § 13–218.1 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.text: The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: bring any civil action necessary to enforce those provisions of this Division I that are subject to the authority of the Secretary or any regulation adopted under them; and
defend any civil action brought against the Secretary or the Department.

subsection.text: A resident of this State may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction:

paragraph.text: to recover, for the use of this State, a payment made in violation of this Division I or of a regulation adopted under it from the person who authorized or made the payment;
to enjoin a person, this State, or a unit of this State from authorizing a payment in violation of this Division I or of a regulation adopted under it; or
if a payroll authorization is provided for by law or regulation, to enjoin the Secretary from issuing a payroll authorization in violation of this Division I or of a regulation adopted under it.

subsection.text: In an action brought under this section, a judgment or other order may not be recorded as “released” or “satisfied” unless the Attorney General files with the court a notice of release or satisfaction.

section.text: Except as otherwise specifically provided by State law, this State, its officers, and its units may not raise the defense of sovereign immunity in any administrative, arbitration, or judicial proceeding involving an employee grievance or hearing that is held under:

paragraph.text: this Division I or a regulation adopted under it; or
a personnel policy or regulation that governs classified employees of the University System of Maryland or Morgan State University.

section.text: In this subtitle, “award” means a final monetary or benefit award or judgment in an administrative, arbitration, or judicial proceeding involving an employee grievance or hearing that is held under:

paragraph.text: this Division I or a regulation adopted under it; or
a personnel policy or regulation that governs classified employees of the University System of Maryland or Morgan State University.

section.text: If this State has sufficient money available at the time, an award made against this State or an officer or unit of this State shall be paid as soon as practicable within 20 days after the award is final.

subsection.text: If sufficient money is not available at the time to satisfy an award made against this State or an officer or unit of this State, the affected unit or officer shall report the outstanding award to the State Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: keep an accounting of all outstanding awards; and
report that accounting annually to the Governor.

subsection.text: The Governor shall include in the State budget sufficient money to pay all awards made against this State or an officer or unit of this State.
On appropriation of money by the General Assembly, the Comptroller shall authorize payment of all outstanding awards in the order of the date on which each award was made.

section.text: A person may not impersonate another in an examination held under this Division I.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: willfully deceive another about the right to take an examination under this Division I; or
willfully interfere with the right of an individual to take an examination under this Division I.

section.text: A person may not willfully falsify:

paragraph.text: an answer on an examination held under this Division I;
a grade or mark on an examination held under this Division I;
a report on the results of an examination held under this Division I; or
a report on the standing of an individual examined under this Division I.

section.text: An applicant for employment may not act deceptively in order to improve the applicant's chances for appointment.

A person may not willfully give to an individual any information about a competitive examination under this article that is not generally available to all competitors for the examination in order to improve or to harm the individual's rating for appointment.

A person may not use or promise to use the person's influence or official authority to secure an appointment or an opportunity for an appointment to a position in the skilled service or professional service in exchange or as a reward for personal service or political service.
An employee or public official of this State may not use a threat or coercion to induce or attempt to induce an employee in the skilled service or professional service:

paragraph.text: to resign;
to take a leave of absence; or
to waive a right granted by this Division I.

section.text: A person may not willfully assist another to commit an act prohibited by this subtitle.

Any person who violates Subtitle 1 of this title or any regulation adopted under it is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

subsection.text: In this Division II the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Accumulated contributions” means the amounts credited to a member’s individual account in the annuity savings fund of the appropriate State system.
“Accumulated contributions” includes:

subparagraph.text: member contributions;
additional contributions; and
regular interest.

subsection.text: “Additional contribution” means a contribution that is made voluntarily by a member.

“Allowance” means a benefit that is payable in equal monthly installments for the life of the recipient, except as otherwise provided for an optional form of an allowance under § 21–403 of this article.

“Alternate Contributory Pension Selection” means the part of the Employees’ Pension System and the Teachers’ Pension System that provides the Alternate Contributory Pension Selection under Title 23, Subtitle 2, Part III of this article.
“Annuity” means the part of an allowance that is derived from the accumulated contributions of a member.
“Annuity reserve” means the present value of an annuity computed on the basis of actuarial assumptions adopted by the Board of Trustees.
“Average final compensation” means the average annual earnable compensation that is computed as provided in § 20–204, § 20–205, or § 20–205.1 of this title.
“Basic allowance” means an allowance computed without modification under § 21–403 of this article.
“Beneficiary” means a person, other than a retiree, in receipt of a benefit under this Division II.
“Board of Trustees” means the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System.

“Contributory pension benefit” means the part of the Employees’ Pension System and the Teachers’ Pension System that provides the contributory pension benefit under Title 23, Subtitle 2, Part II of this article.
“Correctional Officers’ Retirement System” means the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System of the State of Maryland.
“County” means a county of the State and, unless expressly provided otherwise, Baltimore City.
“Creditable service” means the service credit of a member that is recognized for computing a benefit under this Division II.
“Designated beneficiary” means a person named as beneficiary in an acknowledged written designation filed with the Board of Trustees by a member, former member, or a retiree.
“Earnable compensation” means one–twelfth of the member’s annual salary rate payable for working the normal time in the member’s position, including:

paragraph.text: the employer pickup contribution provided for in § 21–312 of this article; or
a contribution made under a salary reduction or supplemental retirement plan in accordance with Title 35 of this article.

subsection.text: “Eligibility service” means the service credit of a member that is recognized for determining eligibility for a benefit under this Division II.
“Employees’ Pension System” means the Employees’ Pension System of the State of Maryland.
“Employees’ Retirement System” means the Employees’ Retirement System of the State of Maryland.
“Employer pickup contribution” means a contribution made through a reduction in a member’s compensation under § 21–313 of this article.
“Former member” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: has been a member;
has separated from employment with a participating employer; and
is not currently a member or retiree.

subsection.text: “Judges’ Retirement System” means the Judges’ Retirement System of the State of Maryland.
“Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System” means the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System of the State of Maryland.

“Legislative Pension Plan” means the Legislative Pension Plan of the State of Maryland as provided by the joint resolution submitted to the General Assembly by the General Assembly Compensation Commission under Article III, § 15 of the Maryland Constitution.
“Local Fire and Police System” means the Local Fire and Police Pension System of the State of Maryland.
“Medical board” means a board of physicians provided for in § 21–126 of this article.
“Member” means, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, an individual:

paragraph.text: for whom membership in a State system is a condition of employment; or

subparagraph.text: for whom membership in a State system is optional; and
who has elected to become a member of that State system.

paragraph.text: “Member contribution” means:

subparagraph.text: a contribution that is deducted from a member’s compensation as required by this Division II;
a contribution that is designated as a member contribution under § 22–212 or § 22–213 of this article;
a contribution that is redeposited as a member contribution;
the part attributable to a member contribution of any payment for the purchase of service credit under this Division II; and
an employer pickup contribution.

paragraph.text: “Member contribution” does not include any additional contribution.

subsection.text: “Noncontributory pension benefit” means the part of the Employees’ Pension System and the Teachers’ Pension System that does not provide the contributory pension benefit under Title 23, Subtitle 2, Part II of this article or the Alternate Contributory Pension Selection under Title 23, Subtitle 2, Part III of this article.
“Normal retirement age” means:

paragraph.text: 50 years old, for a member of:

subparagraph.text: the State Police Retirement System; or
the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System;

paragraph.text: 60 years old, for a member of:

subparagraph.text: the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System, for the purpose of disability retirement only;
the Employees’ Retirement System;
the Judges’ Retirement System;
the Local Fire and Police System, who transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System; or
the Teachers’ Retirement System;

paragraph.text: 62 years old, for a member of:

subparagraph.text: the Employees’ Pension System who is a member on or before June 30, 2011;
the Local Fire and Police System, who has not transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System; or
the Teachers’ Pension System who is a member on or before June 30, 2011; or

paragraph.text: 65 years old, for a member of the Employees’ Pension System or Teachers’ Pension System who begins membership on or after July 1, 2011.

subsection.text: “Participant” means a beneficiary, designated beneficiary, former member, member, or retiree who is or may become eligible to receive a benefit of any type from the several systems.
“Participating employer” means the employer of an individual who, because of the employment relationship, is eligible for membership in a State system.
“Participating governmental unit” means a governmental unit that participates in a State system under Title 31 of this article.
“Pension” means the part of an allowance that is derived from employer contributions.
“Pension reserve” means the present value of a pension, computed on the basis of actuarial assumptions adopted by the Board of Trustees.

paragraph.text: “Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
Unless expressly provided otherwise, “person” does not include a governmental entity or a unit or instrumentality of a governmental entity.

subsection.text: “Reformed contributory pension benefit” means the part of the Employees’ Pension System and the Teachers’ Pension System that provides the reformed contributory pension benefit under Title 23, Subtitle 2, Part IV of this article.
“Regular interest” means interest at the rate payable on accumulated contributions as provided under this Division II for each State system.
“Retiree” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: has separated from employment with a participating employer; and
receives a retirement allowance under this Division II.

subsection.text: “Retirement” means the grant of a retirement allowance under this Division II after separation from employment with a participating employer.

paragraph.text: “Retirement allowance” means an allowance that is payable at the time of separation from employment with a participating employer.
“Retirement allowance” includes:

subparagraph.text: a service retirement allowance; and
a disability retirement allowance.

paragraph.text: “Retirement allowance” does not include a vested allowance.

subsection.text: “Several systems” means the State systems specified in § 21–102 of this article.

“Social Security integration level” means, with respect to the calendar year in which a member retires or otherwise separates from employment, the average yearly amount of earnings for which old age and survivors benefits would be provided under Title II of the federal Social Security Act for an employee who is eligible to receive full old age and survivors benefits provided under Title II of the federal Social Security Act in that calendar year that is:

paragraph.text: computed as though for each previous year yearly earnings are at least equal to the maximum amount of yearly earnings subject to tax under the Federal Insurance Contributions Act; and
rounded to the next lower multiple of $100.

subsection.text: “State Police Retirement System” means the State Police Retirement System of the State of Maryland.
“State system” means a retirement or pension system that is included in the State Retirement and Pension System under § 21–102 of this article.
“Taxable wage base” means, with respect to each calendar year, the maximum amount of annual earnings for employees subject to tax under the federal Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance Act.
“Teachers’ Pension System” means the Teachers’ Pension System of the State of Maryland.
“Teachers’ Retirement System” means the Teachers’ Retirement System of the State of Maryland.

“Vested allowance” means an allowance that is not payable at the time of separation from employment with a participating employer, but is deferred until the former member becomes eligible for immediate payment.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, and except as otherwise expressly provided, Titles 20, 21, and 29 of this article apply to each State system.
Title 21, Subtitle 4 and Titles 22 through 31 of this article do not apply to the Legislative Pension Plan.

section.text: An actuarial equivalent shall be an equivalent amount based on actuarial assumptions adopted by the Board of Trustees.

On retirement, an Executive Branch official, judge, legislator, or other State employee may not receive benefits as a member of more than one State system for the same period of employment as a member.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to an individual who is a member of:

subparagraph.text: the Employees’ Retirement System; or
the Teachers’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the average final compensation of a member equals the average annual earnable compensation of the member for:

subparagraph.text: the 3 years of employment as a member during which the member’s earnable compensation was highest, if the member was employed at least 3 years as a member; or
the member’s total period of employment, if the member was employed less than 3 years as a member.

paragraph.text: Except for a salary increase because of a member’s promotion, the member’s average final compensation does not include a salary increase in the last 3 years of employment if it is an extraordinary salary increase according to regulations that the Board of Trustees adopts.
This subsection applies only to an individual who on or before June 30, 2011, is a member of:

subparagraph.text: the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System; or
the State Police Retirement System.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the average final compensation of a member equals the average annual earnable compensation of the member for:

subparagraph.text: the 3 years of employment as a member during which the member’s earnable compensation was highest, if the member was employed at least 3 years as a member; or
the member’s total period of employment, if the member was employed less than 3 years as a member.

Except for a salary increase because of a member’s promotion, the member’s average final compensation does not include a salary increase in the last 3 years of employment if it is an extraordinary salary increase according to regulations that the Board of Trustees adopts.

sub-subparagraph.text: This subparagraph applies only to a member of the State Police Retirement System.

If a member of the State Police Retirement System who transferred from another actuarial retirement system in the State retires after less than 3 years of employment as a member of the State Police Retirement System, the earnable compensation as a member in the other system shall be used in the determination of average final compensation.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to an individual who on or after July 1, 2011, becomes a member of:

subparagraph.text: the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System; or
the State Police Retirement System.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the average final compensation of a member equals the average annual earnable compensation of the member for:

subparagraph.text: the 5 years of employment as a member during which the member’s earnable compensation was highest, if the member was employed at least 5 years as a member; or
the member’s total period of employment, if the member was employed less than 5 years as a member.

Except for a salary increase because of a member’s promotion, the member’s average final compensation does not include a salary increase in the last 5 years of employment if it is an extraordinary salary increase according to regulations that the Board of Trustees adopts.

sub-subparagraph.text: This subparagraph applies only to a member of the State Police Retirement System.

If a member of the State Police Retirement System who transferred from another actuarial retirement system in the State retires after less than 5 years of employment as a member of the State Police Retirement System, the earnable compensation as a member in the other system shall be used in the determination of average final compensation.

subsection.text: This section applies only to an individual who on or before June 30, 2011, is a member of:

paragraph.text: the Employees’ Pension System;
the Local Fire and Police System;
the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System; or
the Teachers’ Pension System.
In this subsection, “break in service” means a period of employment in which the member’s employer did not:

subparagraph.text: deduct the member contributions from the compensation of the member; or
report the hours worked by the member.

For the purpose of computing benefits under this Division II, the average final compensation of a member equals the average annual earnable compensation of the member, adjusted as provided in this section, during the 3 consecutive years that provide the highest average earnable compensation.
If the member experienced any break in service during the 3 consecutive years that provide the member’s highest average earnable compensation, the Board of Trustees:

sub-subparagraph.text: may not include in the computation of average final compensation the period of months of the breaks in service, that otherwise would be included in the computation; and
in order to generate the highest average earnable compensation for the member, shall extend the 3-year period by an equal number of months immediately preceding or following that period.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to a member of the Employees’ Pension System or Teachers’ Pension System who is subject to the noncontributory pension benefit and who was on authorized leave of absence at partial pay or without pay during the last 3 years of employment as a member.
If the period used to determine average final compensation is the period that immediately precedes the date of retirement or other separation from employment, the Board of Trustees:

subparagraph.text: may not include in the computation of average final compensation the period of months of the leave of absence, not exceeding 12, that otherwise would be included in the computation; and
shall substitute an equal number of months immediately preceding that period.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to a member whose eligibility service has been adjusted under this Division II to compute creditable service, on the basis of the member having completed less than the normal hours of service for the member’s position.
A member’s earnable compensation shall be adjusted to a full-time basis for any period included in the computation of average final compensation.

subsection.text: Except for a salary increase because of a member’s promotion, the member’s average final compensation does not include a salary increase in the last 3 years of employment if it is an extraordinary salary increase according to regulations that the Board of Trustees adopts.
This section applies only to an individual who on or after July 1, 2011, becomes a member of:

paragraph.text: the Employees’ Pension System;
the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System; or
the Teachers’ Pension System.
In this subsection, “break in service” means a period of employment in which the member’s employer did not:

subparagraph.text: deduct the member contributions from the compensation of the member; or
report the hours worked by the member.

For the purpose of computing benefits under this Division II, the average final compensation of a member equals the average annual earnable compensation of the member, adjusted as provided in this section, during the 5 consecutive years that provide the highest average earnable compensation.
If the member experienced any break in service during the 5 consecutive years that provide the member’s highest average earnable compensation, the Board of Trustees:

sub-subparagraph.text: may not include in the computation of average final compensation the period of months of the breaks in service that otherwise would be included in the computation; and
in order to generate the highest average earnable compensation for the member, shall extend the 5–year period by an equal number of months immediately preceding or following that period.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to a member whose eligibility service has been adjusted under this Division II to compute creditable service, on the basis of the member having completed less than the normal hours of service for the member’s position.
A member’s earnable compensation shall be adjusted to a full–time basis for any period included in the computation of average final compensation.

subsection.text: Except for a salary increase because of a member’s promotion, the member’s average final compensation does not include a salary increase in the last 5 years of employment if it is an extraordinary salary increase according to regulations that the Board of Trustees adopts.
In this section, “unused sick leave” means sick leave credit that has not been used before retirement.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the Judges’ Retirement System; or
the Legislative Pension Plan.

subsection.text: A member is entitled to receive creditable service for unused sick leave if the member retires on or before 30 days after the member is separated from employment with a participating employer or a participating governmental unit that has withdrawn from one of the several systems under Title 31 of this article.

paragraph.text: At retirement, a member is entitled to receive creditable service for unused sick leave, on verification of the unused sick leave to the Board of Trustees.

subparagraph.text: This subsection does not apply to the Local Fire and Police System or the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System.

A member who separates from employment for reasons other than retirement on or before June 30, 1990, is entitled to receive creditable service for unused sick leave that is reported by the member’s employer at the member’s separation from employment if the member was entitled to a vested allowance at the time of separation.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, for 22 days of unused sick leave a member is entitled to receive 1 month of creditable service.

If fractional days totaling 11 or more result from the application of the formula described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, a member is entitled to receive 1 additional month of creditable service.
For the purposes of this section:

subparagraph.text: a member may not accumulate more than 15 days of sick leave per year;
unless sick leave credit is accepted and credited by the current participating employer, a member may not receive credit for unused sick leave granted by a former employer; and

if a participating employer provides a member with more than 15 days of sick leave per year, before crediting the member with additional sick leave for a year, the Board of Trustees shall reduce the member’s accumulated sick leave by the lesser of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the days of sick leave used by the member in that year; or
the number of days of sick leave provided by the participating employer for the year, less 15.

subsection.text: Credit for unused sick leave may not be used under this section:

paragraph.text: to determine years of eligibility service required for a benefit under this Division II; or
to compute average final compensation.

subsection.text: A State employee who came into the State system while retaining sick leave and annual leave benefits under a county system and who came under the provisions of Chapter 423 of the Acts of 1971 shall be entitled to the same full credit toward retirement as provided by this section.
This section does not apply to an individual who is a member of a State system on or before June 30, 1996.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law, for plan years beginning on or after July 1, 1996, the annual compensation that may be taken into account when determining the retirement allowance payable to a member of a State system, may not exceed the compensation limit under § 401(a)(17)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code and regulations adopted thereunder.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Board of Trustees may not pay an allowance that exceeds the limit on benefit accruals established from time to time under § 415 of the Internal Revenue Code.
Subject to subsections (c) and (d) of this section, the Agency shall reduce:

paragraph.text: an allowance to the extent that it exceeds the dollar limit on an annual benefit established from time to time under § 415(b) of the Internal Revenue Code and the regulations adopted thereunder; and

the contributions and other additions to any defined contribution plan maintained by the Board of Trustees to the extent that they exceed the limit on annual additions established from time to time under § 415(c) of the Internal Revenue Code and the regulations adopted thereunder.

The dollar limit on an annual benefit is the amount set forth in § 415(b) of the Internal Revenue Code, as adjusted by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue under § 415(d) of the Internal Revenue Code as of January 1 of each calendar year.
The dollar limit for a calendar year applies to a State system’s fiscal year ending within that calendar year.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Agency shall pay a participant whose allowance was reduced under subsection (b) of this section any postretirement adjustment if payment of the postretirement adjustment does not exceed the dollar limit on benefits.
The postretirement adjustment may not exceed a participant’s basic allowance as increased by any postretirement adjustments allowable under the applicable State system.

subsection.text: If an individual participates in any other retirement or pension system that must be aggregated with the State system administered by the Board of Trustees, the individual’s annual benefit accrual or annual addition shall first be reduced by the other retirement or pension system to the extent necessary to comply with the requirements of § 415 of the Internal Revenue Code and the regulations adopted thereunder before any reduction is made by the Board of Trustees.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to an individual who is a member of a State system on or before June 30, 1999.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Agency may not allow a member to purchase prior service credit other than in accordance with the limitations and conditions set forth in § 415(n) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: A member may purchase prior service credit using funds from any fund source that is not specifically prohibited by the Internal Revenue Code.

In conformity with § 401(a)(8) of the Internal Revenue Code, any forfeiture of benefits by a member or former member of the several systems may not be used by the Board of Trustees to pay benefit increases.
Any forfeiture of benefits by a member shall be used to reduce employer contributions.
There is a State Retirement and Pension System.
The State Retirement and Pension System shall provide benefits under this Division II for participants in the several systems.
The State Retirement and Pension System has the powers and privileges of a corporation.

section.text: The State Retirement and Pension System consists of:

paragraph.text: the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System, established on July 1, 1974;
the Employees’ Pension System, established on January 1, 1980;
the Employees’ Retirement System, established on October 1, 1941;
the Judges’ Retirement System, which consists of:

subparagraph.text: the contributory plan, established on July 1, 1969; and
the noncontributory plan, established on April 7, 1904;

paragraph.text: the Legislative Pension Plan;
