subparagraph.text: The Board of Trustees shall adopt regulations to determine for any fiscal year the amount of creditable service that equals the eligibility service for a member who has completed less than the normal hours of employment for the member’s position.
The normal hours of employment for a position equals the minimum number of hours to be completed by a full-time employee serving in the member’s position.
The creditable service recognized for a fiscal year may not be less than the eligibility service for the member multiplied by a fraction, not to exceed one, that has:

sub-subparagraph.text: as its numerator, the number of hours of employment as a member that the member has completed during that year; and
as its denominator, the normal number of hours for the member’s position.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, a member may retire with a normal service retirement allowance if, on or before the date of retirement, the member:

subparagraph.text: has at least 25 years of eligibility service;
is at least 62 years old; or
is at least 60 years old and has transferred to the Local Fire and Police System from the Employees’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: To retire under this subsection, a member shall complete and submit a written application to the Board of Trustees on the form that the Board of Trustees provides stating the date when the member desires to retire.
A member may not retire before the first day of the month after employment ends.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, on retirement under this section, a member is entitled to receive a normal service retirement allowance that equals the number of years of the member’s creditable service multiplied by:

paragraph.text: 1% of the member’s average final compensation that is not in excess of the Social Security integration level; and
1.5% of the member’s average final compensation that exceeds the Social Security integration level.
This subsection applies to a member:

subparagraph.text: who has not transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System; and
whose employer does not contribute to Social Security.

paragraph.text: On retirement under this section, a member is entitled to receive a normal service retirement allowance that equals the number of years of the member’s creditable service multiplied by 1.5% of the member’s average final compensation.
This subsection applies to a member who has transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System.
On retirement under this section, a member is entitled to receive a normal service retirement allowance that equals:

subparagraph.text: 2% of the member’s average final compensation multiplied by each year of the member’s first 30 years of creditable service; and
1% of the member’s average final compensation multiplied by each year of creditable service in excess of 30 years.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (g) of this section, an individual who is receiving a service retirement allowance or vested allowance may accept employment with a participating employer on a permanent, temporary, or contractual basis, without any reduction in the allowance, if:

paragraph.text: the individual immediately notifies the Board of Trustees of the individual’s intention to accept the employment; and
the individual specifies the compensation to be received.

The Board of Trustees shall reduce the allowance of an individual who accepts employment as provided under subsection (a) of this section if the individual’s current employer is a participating employer other than the State and is the same participating employer that employed the individual at the time of the individual’s last separation from employment with a participating employer before the individual commenced receiving a service retirement allowance or vested allowance.

The reduction required under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall equal the amount that the sum of the individual’s initial annual basic allowance and the individual’s annual compensation exceeds the average final compensation used to compute the basic allowance.
Except for an individual whose allowance is subject to a reduction as provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the reduction of an allowance under this subsection does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: an individual whose average final compensation was less than $10,000 and who is reemployed on a temporary or contractual basis;
an individual who is serving in an elected position as an official of a participating governmental unit or as a constitutional officer for a county that is a participating governmental unit; or
an individual who has been retired for 9 years, beginning on January 1 after the date the individual retires.

subsection.text: An individual who is receiving a service retirement allowance or a vested allowance and who is reemployed by a participating employer may not receive creditable service or eligibility service during the period of reemployment.

The individual’s compensation during the period of reemployment may not be subject to the employer pickup provisions of § 21-303 of this article or any reduction or deduction as a member contribution for pension or retirement purposes.
The State Retirement Agency shall institute appropriate reporting procedures with the affected payroll systems to ensure compliance with this section.

paragraph.text: Immediately on the employment of any individual receiving a service retirement allowance or a vested allowance, a participating employer shall notify the State Retirement Agency of the type of employment and the anticipated earnings of the individual.

At least once each year, in a format specified by the State Retirement Agency, each participating employer shall provide the State Retirement Agency with a list of all employees included on any payroll of the employer, the Social Security numbers of the employees, and their earnings for that year.

subsection.text: An individual who is rehired under this section may not be rehired within 45 days of the date the individual retired if the individual’s current employer is a participating employer other than the State and is the same participating employer that employed the individual at the time of the individual’s last separation from employment with a participating employer before the individual commenced receiving a service retirement allowance.

section.text: A member may be entitled to benefits under Title 29 of this article other than, or in addition to, the benefits provided under this subtitle.
This subtitle does not apply to the Judges’ Retirement System.

Before the Board of Trustees grants a retirement allowance for a disability, an application must be completed and submitted to the Board of Trustees in accordance with §§ 29-103 and 29-104 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to § 29–104 of this subtitle, an application for disability retirement may be submitted:

paragraph.text: by a member;
by a former member;
by a surviving beneficiary of a deceased member; or
for a member, as provided in subsections (b) through (d) of this section.
This subsection does not apply to members of:

subparagraph.text: the State Police Retirement System;
the Teachers’ Pension System; or
the Teachers’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: If a member is unable to apply, the member’s department head may complete and submit an application to the Board of Trustees for the member.
This subsection applies to a member of the State Police Retirement System.
The Secretary of State Police may complete an application and submit it to the Board of Trustees for a member if:

subparagraph.text: the member is unable or refuses to submit an application for disability retirement;
the Secretary believes the member to be permanently physically or mentally incapable of performing assigned duties;

there is sufficient medical evidence in the form of a professional opinion of an independent medical practitioner who has recognized expertise in the diagnosis and treatment of the specified illness of the officer to support the Secretary’s determination of permanent disability;
the onset of the disability occurred at least 1 year earlier; and
any administrative leave granted under § 2-410 of the Public Safety Article has expired.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not prevent an officer from exercising rights granted under § 21-111(b) of this article.
This subsection applies to members of:

subparagraph.text: the Teachers’ Pension System; and
the Teachers’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: If a member is unable to apply, the member’s State or county superintendent may complete and submit an application to the Board of Trustees for the member.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section and subject to subsection (e) of this section, an application for disability retirement must be submitted before the date membership ends.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to an application for an ordinary or accidental disability retirement allowance filed by a member of the Employees’ Pension System or the Teachers’ Pension System who is not subject to the contributory pension benefit or the Alternate Contributory Pension Selection and who separated from employment on or before June 30, 2005.
For the purpose of submitting an application for disability, membership continues for 4 years after paid employment ends.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board of Trustees may accept an application for ordinary, accidental, or special disability retirement from a former member within 24 months after the month membership ended if the former member proves to the satisfaction of the medical board that failure to submit an application while a member was attributable solely to physical or mental incapacity during the filing period.

The Board of Trustees may accept an application for ordinary or accidental disability retirement from a former member of the Teachers’ Retirement System within 12 months after the month membership ended if the former member of the Teachers’ Retirement System proves to the satisfaction of the medical board that failure to submit an application while a member of the Teachers’ Retirement System was attributable solely to physical or mental incapacity during the filing period.

If the Board of Trustees accepts a disability retirement application under this subsection and grants a disability retirement allowance, the retirement allowance begins as of the first day of the month after the Board of Trustees receives the application.

The Board of Trustees shall accept an application for ordinary, accidental, or special disability retirement from a surviving beneficiary of a deceased member, if a preliminary application for disability retirement or an application for disability retirement:

subparagraph.text: is signed and dated by the deceased member within 7 days before the death of the member; and
is received by the Board of Trustees on or before 30 days after the date of the death of the member.

paragraph.text: If the Board of Trustees receives an application under paragraph (1) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: the medical board shall review the application to determine if the deceased member was mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of the normal duties of the individual’s position; and

the Board of Trustees shall review the application to determine if the preliminary application for disability retirement or the application for disability retirement was signed by the deceased member before the death of the member.

paragraph.text: The Board of Trustees shall grant a disability retirement allowance, if:

subparagraph.text: the medical board determines that the deceased member would have been eligible for disability retirement at the time the deceased member signed the disability application; and
the Board of Trustees determines that the signature is valid.

paragraph.text: In order for the signature to be valid, a surviving beneficiary shall submit to the Board of Trustees an affidavit signed by an individual who witnessed the deceased member signing the preliminary application for disability retirement or the application for disability retirement before the death of the member.

If the Board of Trustees accepts a disability retirement application under this subsection and grants a disability retirement allowance, the retirement allowance begins as of the first day of the month after the Board of Trustees receives the application.

subsection.text: (1) This subsection does not apply to an application for special disability under the State Police Retirement System or an application for accidental disability under the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System or to an application for accidental disability under the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: The Board of Trustees may not accept an application for accidental disability filed by a member or former member more than 5 years after the date of the claimed accident.

subsection.text: The Board of Trustees shall grant an ordinary disability retirement allowance to a member if:

paragraph.text: the member has at least 5 years of eligibility service; and
the medical board certifies that:

subparagraph.text: the member is mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of the normal duties of the member’s position;
the incapacity is likely to be permanent; and
the member should be retired.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to a member of the Employees’ Pension System who:

subparagraph.text: is promoted within the Department of Corrections to a position that no longer is eligible for membership in the Correctional Officers’ Pension System as provided in § 25-201 of this article;
elects not to transfer the years of creditable service the individual accrued in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System to the Employees’ Pension System; and
is eligible to receive a vested allowance from the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: A member may combine the eligibility service accrued in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System and the Employees’ Pension System to determine if the member is eligible for an ordinary disability retirement allowance under subsection (a) of this section from the Employees’ Pension System.

subsection.text: This section applies only to members of:

paragraph.text: the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System;
the Employees’ Retirement System; and
the Teachers’ Retirement System.

subsection.text: An ordinary disability retirement allowance equals the greater of:

paragraph.text: a normal service retirement allowance; or
the amount computed under subsection (c) or (d) of this section.

subsection.text: If a member is at least normal retirement age, the amount to be used under subsection (b)(2) of this section is 25% of the member’s average final compensation.
If a member is under normal retirement age, the amount to be used under subsection (b)(2) of this section is the lesser of:

paragraph.text: 25% of the member’s average final compensation; or
the normal service retirement allowance that is computed by using:

subparagraph.text: the number of years of creditable service that the member would have received if the member continued employment until normal retirement age; and
an average final compensation that the member would have received if the member continued employment without a change in earnable compensation.

subsection.text: This section applies only to members of the State Police Retirement System.
An ordinary disability retirement allowance equals the greater of:

paragraph.text: a normal service retirement allowance; or
35% of the member’s average final compensation.

subsection.text: This section applies only to members of:

paragraph.text: the Employees’ Pension System;
the Local Fire and Police System;
the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System; and
the Teachers’ Pension System.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (c), (d), and (e) of this section, an ordinary disability retirement allowance equals:

paragraph.text: if the member is at least normal retirement age, a normal service retirement allowance; or
if the member is under normal retirement age, a normal service retirement allowance that is computed by using:

subparagraph.text: the number of years of creditable service the member would have received if the member continued employment until normal retirement age; and
an average final compensation the member would have received if the member continued employment without a change in earnable compensation.

subsection.text: A member of the Employees’ Pension System or the Teachers’ Pension System who has transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System or the Teachers’ Retirement System shall receive the benefits provided under the State system from which the member transferred, offset by any refunded contributions including any interest received in connection with the transfer, if:

paragraph.text: the member applies for the retirement allowance within 2 years after the transfer; and
the Board of Trustees grants a disability retirement allowance to the member.
This subsection applies only to:

subparagraph.text: a member of the Local Fire and Police Pension System who has transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System; or

a member of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System who has transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System after electing to receive benefits in accordance with Selection A (Additional member contributions) as defined in § 22-101(b) of this article or Selection B (Limited cost-of-living adjustment) as defined in § 22-101(c) of this article.

paragraph.text: An ordinary disability retirement allowance equals the greater of:

subparagraph.text: a normal service retirement allowance; or
25% of the member’s average final compensation.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to a member of the Employees’ Pension System who:

subparagraph.text: is promoted within the Department of Corrections to a position that no longer is eligible for membership in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System as provided in § 25-201 of this article;
elects not to transfer the years of creditable service the individual accrued in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System to the Employees’ Pension System; and
is eligible to receive a vested allowance from the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: An ordinary disability retirement allowance equals:

subparagraph.text: a normal service retirement allowance in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System based on the member’s total years of creditable service accrued in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System; plus
an ordinary disability retirement allowance based on the member’s total years of creditable service accrued in the Employees’ Pension System.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to the State Police Retirement System.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the Board of Trustees shall grant an accidental disability retirement allowance to a member if:

paragraph.text: the member is totally and permanently incapacitated for duty as the natural and proximate result of an accident that occurred in the actual performance of duty at a definite time and place without willful negligence by the member; and
the medical board certifies that:

subparagraph.text: the member is mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of the normal duties of the member’s position;
the incapacity is likely to be permanent; and
the member should be retired.

subsection.text: The Board of Trustees shall grant an accidental disability retirement allowance to a member of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System if:

paragraph.text: the member is totally and permanently incapacitated for duty arising out of or in the course of the actual performance of duty without willful negligence by the member; and
the medical board certifies that:

subparagraph.text: the member is totally incapacitated, either mentally or physically, for the further performance of duty;
the incapacity is likely to be permanent; and
the member should be retired.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to the State Police Retirement System.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, an accidental disability retirement allowance equals the lesser of:

paragraph.text: the member’s average final compensation; or
the sum of:

subparagraph.text: an annuity that is the actuarial equivalent of the member’s accumulated contributions at retirement; and
a pension equal to two-thirds of the member’s average final compensation.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to a member of a State system other than the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System who is at least normal retirement age.
An accidental disability retirement allowance equals the greater of:

subparagraph.text: a normal service retirement allowance; or
an accidental disability retirement allowance computed in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to a member of the Employees’ Pension System who:

subparagraph.text: is promoted within the Department of Corrections to a position that no longer is eligible for membership in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System as provided in § 25-201 of this article;
elects not to transfer the years of creditable service the individual accrued in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System to the Employees’ Pension System; and
is eligible to receive a vested allowance from the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: A member may receive an accidental disability retirement allowance under this section if the member:

subparagraph.text: does not elect to receive a vested allowance from the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System; and
transfers the member’s accumulated contributions in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System to the Employees’ Pension System.

subsection.text: This section applies to the State Police Retirement System.
Except as provided in § 24–401.1(k) of this article, the Board of Trustees shall grant a special disability retirement allowance to a member if:

paragraph.text: the member is totally and permanently incapacitated for duty arising out of or in the course of the actual performance of duty without willful negligence by the member; and
the medical board certifies that:

subparagraph.text: the member is totally incapacitated, either mentally or physically, for the further performance of duty;
the incapacity is likely to be permanent; and
the member should be retired.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, a special disability retirement allowance equals the lesser of:

paragraph.text: the member’s average final compensation; or
the sum of:

subparagraph.text: an annuity that is the actuarial equivalent of the member’s accumulated contributions at retirement; and
a pension equal to two–thirds of the member’s average final compensation.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to a member who is at least normal retirement age.
A special disability retirement allowance equals the greater of:

subparagraph.text: a normal service retirement allowance; or
a special disability retirement allowance computed in accordance with subsection (c) of this section.

section.text: If the Board of Trustees approves an application for disability retirement for a member of the State Police Retirement System that was filed by the Secretary of State Police under § 29-103(c) of this subtitle or § 2-415(b) of the Public Safety Article, the member:

paragraph.text: within 90 days after approval, may exercise an option as provided under §§ 21-402 and 21-403 of this article; or
shall receive the basic allowance.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, a disability retiree of the State Police Retirement System, or a beneficiary of a disability retiree of the State Police Retirement System, who retires on or before June 30, 1999 with an ordinary or special disability retirement allowance under § 29-107 or § 29-111 of this subtitle, shall receive an annual retirement allowance adjustment as of July 1, 1999, as follows:

paragraph.text: for a retiree who has been retired not more than 5 years, $1,200;
for a retiree who has been retired more than 5 years but not more than 10 years, $1,500;
for a retiree who has been retired more than 10 years but not more than 15 years, $1,800; and
for a retiree who has been retired more than 15 years, $2,100.

subsection.text: Each fiscal year, the Board of Trustees shall increase the adjustment received by the retiree or the beneficiary as of July 1, 1999, by multiplying the adjustment by a fraction that has:

paragraph.text: as its numerator, the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 of the preceding fiscal year; and
as its denominator, the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31, 1998.

section.text: A member entitled to an accidental disability retirement allowance or a special disability retirement allowance may not receive a retirement allowance for ordinary disability.

paragraph.text: This section applies only to a disability retiree who is not eligible to receive a normal service retirement.
This section does not apply to a disability retiree who is:

subparagraph.text: a retiree of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the State Police Retirement System;
the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System;
the Local Fire and Police System; or

the Employees’ Retirement System or the Employees’ Pension System, if at the time of retirement the retiree was a law enforcement officer for a participating employer under § 26–201(a) of this article; and

subparagraph.text: reemployed by a participating employer in any position other than a probationary status law enforcement officer, a law enforcement officer, or chief, as defined in § 3–101 of the Public Safety Article.
The Board of Trustees shall, after giving notice, temporarily suspend the retiree’s allowance if the retiree:

sub-subparagraph.text: began receiving a disability retirement allowance on or after July 1, 1998; and
is employed by a participating employer at an annual compensation that is at least equal to the retiree’s average final compensation at retirement.

subparagraph.text: A temporary suspension under this subsection shall begin as of the date the retiree is reemployed by a participating employer under subparagraph (i)2 of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: A retiree whose allowance is temporarily suspended under this subsection is not subject to a reduction as provided in § 29–116 of this subtitle during the period of employment by a participating employer.

Upon receiving satisfactory documentation that the retiree is no longer employed by a participating employer, the Board of Trustees shall reinstate the retiree’s allowance with accumulated cost–of–living adjustments from the date the allowance was temporarily suspended.
The retiree’s allowance will be reinstated on the first day of the month following the month in which the retiree ceased employment with the participating employer.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a retiree who is:

paragraph.text: a retiree of:

subparagraph.text: the State Police Retirement System;
the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System;
the Local Fire and Police System; or

the Employees’ Retirement System or the Employees’ Pension System, if at the time of retirement the retiree was a law enforcement officer for a participating employer under § 26–201(a) of this article; and

paragraph.text: reemployed by a participating employer in any position other than a probationary status law enforcement officer, a law enforcement officer, or chief, as defined in § 3–101 of the Public Safety Article.

subsection.text: The Board of Trustees shall reduce the pension of a retiree on ordinary disability if:

paragraph.text: the retiree is under normal retirement age;
the medical board certifies in a report to the Board of Trustees that the retiree is employed by a participating employer at an annual compensation that is greater than the difference between:

subparagraph.text: the retiree’s retirement allowance at retirement; and
the retiree’s average final compensation plus $5,000;

paragraph.text: the Board of Trustees agrees with the medical board’s report; and
the retiree’s allowance has not been temporarily suspended as provided in § 29–115 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board of Trustees shall reduce the pension of a retiree who has been receiving an ordinary disability retirement allowance for:

paragraph.text: less than 10 years, by $1 for every $2 that the retiree’s current compensation exceeds the limit under subsection (b) of this section; or
at least 10 years, by $1 for every $5 that the retiree’s current compensation exceeds the limit under subsection (b) of this section.

subsection.text: The pension to be reduced under this section is the pension at retirement without any cost–of–living adjustment.
A disability retiree who is rehired by a participating employer may not receive creditable service or eligibility service during the period of reemployment.

The disability retiree’s compensation during the period of reemployment may not be subject to the employer pickup provisions of § 21-303 of this article or any reduction or deduction as a member contribution for pension or retirement purposes.
The State Retirement Agency shall institute appropriate reporting procedures with the affected payroll systems to ensure compliance with this section.

paragraph.text: Immediately on the employment of any retiree, a participating employer shall notify the State Retirement Agency of the type of employment and the anticipated earnings of the retiree.

At least once each year, in a format specified by the State Retirement Agency, each participating employer shall provide the State Retirement Agency with a list of all employees included on any payroll of the employer, the Social Security numbers of the employees, and their earnings for that year.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, this section applies to a retiree and any designated beneficiary.

subparagraph.text: This section does not apply to:

sub-subparagraph.text: a retiree of a participating governmental unit, or a designated beneficiary of that retiree; or

a retiree of the Employees’ Pension System or the Employees’ Retirement System who receives a disability retirement benefit as a former employee of a county board of education or the Board of School Commissioners of Baltimore City, or a designated beneficiary of that retiree.

subparagraph.text: A retiree described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, or a designated beneficiary of that retiree is subject to § 9–610 of the Labor and Employment Article.

paragraph.text: The Board of Trustees shall reduce an accidental or special disability retirement benefit by any related workers’ compensation benefits paid or payable after the effective date of retirement if the workers’ compensation benefits:

subparagraph.text: are paid or payable while a pension is paid or payable; and
are for an accidental personal injury arising out of and in the course of the retiree’s employment by a participating employer.

paragraph.text: A retirement allowance may not be reduced:

subparagraph.text: to be less than the sum of the retiree’s annuity and the amount authorized to be deducted for health insurance premiums; or
for workers’ compensation benefits that are reimbursements for legal fees, medical expenses, or other payments made to third parties and not to the retiree.

subsection.text: The retirement allowance to be reduced under this section is the retirement allowance at retirement without any cost-of-living adjustment and is retroactive.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to the Judges’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: When the Board of Trustees receives proof of death of an individual who died while employed as a member, the Board of Trustees shall pay to the designated beneficiary or, if there is no designated beneficiary, to the member’s estate the amounts specified in this subsection.
Subject to paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board of Trustees shall pay the member’s accumulated contributions.

Subject to paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board of Trustees shall pay an amount equal to the member’s annual earnable compensation at death if the member dies in the course of the performance of duty or the member has at least 1 year of eligibility service.

A death benefit under this section may not be paid for the death of a member of the State Police Retirement System if a special death benefit under § 29–204 of this subtitle is payable or has been paid for that death.

A death benefit under this section may not be paid for the death of a member of the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System if a special death benefit under § 29–204.1 of this subtitle is payable or has been paid for that death.

A death benefit under this section may not be paid for the death of a member of the Employees’ Retirement System, Employees’ Pension System, Teachers’ Retirement System, or Teachers’ Pension System if a special death benefit under § 29–204.2 of this subtitle is payable or has been paid for that death.

A death benefit under this section may not be paid for the death of a member of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System if a special death benefit under § 29–203 of this subtitle is payable or has been paid for that death.

subsection.text: The Board of Trustees may provide the death benefit as group life insurance if the Board of Trustees finds that the designated beneficiaries would receive a more favorable tax treatment of the death benefit.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to an individual who dies while employed as a member of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System:

subparagraph.text: without willful negligence by the member; and
with more than 2 years of eligibility service.

paragraph.text: When the Board of Trustees receives proof of death of a member and finds that the death has occurred in the manner described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board of Trustees shall pay:

subparagraph.text: if the member is survived by a spouse or child under the age of 18 years:

sub-subparagraph.text: the member’s accumulated contributions to the designated beneficiary, or otherwise to the member’s estate; and
an allowance of 50% of the ordinary disability retirement allowance provided for in § 29-108 of this title:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: to the surviving spouse; or
if there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse dies before the youngest child of the member is 18 years old, to any children of the deceased member who are under the age of 18 years; or

subparagraph.text: if the member is not survived by a spouse or child under the age of 18 years, the death benefit under § 29-202 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to an individual who dies while employed as a member of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System:

subparagraph.text: without willful negligence by the member; and
with death arising out of or in the course of the actual performance of duty.

paragraph.text: When the Board of Trustees receives proof of death of a member and finds that the death has occurred in the manner described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board of Trustees shall pay:

subparagraph.text: if the member is survived by a spouse or child under the age of 18 years:

sub-subparagraph.text: the member’s accumulated contributions to the designated beneficiary, or otherwise to the member’s estate; and
an allowance of two-thirds of the member’s average final compensation:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: to the surviving spouse; or
if there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse dies before the youngest child of the member is 18 years old, to any children of the deceased member who are under the age of 18 years; or

subparagraph.text: if the member is not survived by a spouse or child under the age of 18 years, the death benefit under § 29-202 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If the Board of Trustees pays an allowance under this section to more than one child, the Board of Trustees shall divide the allowance among the children under the age of 18 years in a manner that provides for payments to continue until each child dies or becomes 18 years old.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to an individual who dies while employed as a member of the State Police Retirement System:

subparagraph.text: without willful negligence by the member; and
with more than 2 years of eligibility service.

paragraph.text: When the Board of Trustees receives proof of death of a member and finds that the death has occurred in the manner described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board of Trustees shall pay:

subparagraph.text: if the member is survived by a spouse, a child under the age of 18 years, or a dependent parent:

sub-subparagraph.text: the member’s accumulated contributions to the designated beneficiary, or otherwise to the member’s estate; and
an allowance of 50% of the member’s average final compensation:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: to the surviving spouse;
if there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse dies before the youngest child of the member is 18 years old, to all children under the age of 18 years; or
if there is no surviving spouse or children younger than 18 years of age, to the member’s dependent parent to continue as the Board of Trustees may direct for the rest of the parent’s life; or

subparagraph.text: if the member is not survived by a spouse, a child under the age of 18 years, or a dependent parent, the death benefit under § 29-202 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to an individual who dies while employed as a member of the State Police Retirement System:

subparagraph.text: without willful negligence by the member; and
with death arising out of or in the course of the actual performance of duty.

paragraph.text: When the Board of Trustees receives proof of death of a member and finds that the death has occurred in the manner described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board of Trustees shall pay:

subparagraph.text: if the member is survived by a spouse, a child under the age of 18 years, or a dependent parent:

sub-subparagraph.text: the member’s accumulated contributions to the designated beneficiary, or otherwise to the member’s estate; and
an allowance of two-thirds of the member’s average final compensation:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: to the surviving spouse;
if there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse dies before the youngest child of the member is 18 years old, to all children under the age of 18 years; or
if there is no surviving spouse or children younger than 18 years of age, to the member’s dependent parent to continue as the Board of Trustees may direct for the rest of the parent’s life; or

subparagraph.text: if the member is not survived by a spouse, a child under the age of 18 years, or a dependent parent, the death benefit under § 29-202 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If the Board of Trustees pays an allowance under this section to more than one child, the Board of Trustees shall divide the allowance among the children under the age of 18 years in a manner that provides for payments to continue until each child dies or becomes 18 years old.
This section applies only to an individual who dies while employed as a member of the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System:

paragraph.text: without willful negligence by the member; and
with death arising out of or in the course of the actual performance of duty.

subsection.text: When the Board of Trustees receives proof of death of a member and finds that the death has occurred in the manner described in subsection (a) of this section, the Board of Trustees shall pay:

paragraph.text: if the member is survived by a spouse or a child under the age of 18 years:

subparagraph.text: the member’s accumulated contributions to the designated beneficiary, or otherwise to the member’s estate; and
an allowance of two-thirds of the member’s average final compensation:

sub-subparagraph.text: to the surviving spouse; or
if there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse dies before the youngest child of the member is 18 years old, to any children of the deceased member who are under the age of 18 years; or

paragraph.text: if the member is not survived by a spouse or a child under the age of 18 years, the death benefit under § 29-202 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If the Board of Trustees pays an allowance under this section to more than one child, the Board of Trustees shall divide the allowance among the children under the age of 18 years in a manner that provides for payments to continue until each child dies or becomes 18 years old.
This section applies only to an individual who is killed while a member of the Employees’ Retirement System, Employees’ Pension System, Teachers’ Retirement System, or Teachers’ Pension System:

paragraph.text: without willful negligence by the member; and
with death arising out of or in the course of the actual performance of duty.

subsection.text: When the Board of Trustees receives proof of death of a member and finds that the death has occurred in the manner described in subsection (a) of this section, the Board of Trustees shall pay:

paragraph.text: if the member is survived by a spouse, a child under the age of 18 years, or a dependent parent:

subparagraph.text: the member’s accumulated contributions to the designated beneficiary, or otherwise to the member’s estate; and
an allowance of two–thirds of the member’s average final compensation:

sub-subparagraph.text: to the surviving spouse;
if there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse dies before the youngest child of the member is 18 years old, to all children of the deceased member who are under the age of 18 years; or
if there is no surviving spouse or children younger than 18 years of age, to the member’s dependent parent to continue as the Board of Trustees may direct for the rest of the parent’s life; or

paragraph.text: if the member is not survived by a spouse, a child under the age of 18 years, or a dependent parent, the death benefit under § 29–202 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If the Board of Trustees pays an allowance under this section to more than one child, the Board of Trustees shall divide the allowance among the children under the age of 18 years in a manner that provides for payments to continue until each child dies or becomes 18 years old.
This section applies to the surviving spouse of an individual who died while employed as a member of:

paragraph.text: the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System;
the Employees’ Retirement System;
the Local Fire and Police System, if the member had transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System; or
the Teachers’ Retirement System.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, a surviving spouse may elect to receive one of the following:

paragraph.text: the death benefit, under § 29–202 of this subtitle; or
an allowance equal to the amount payable under Option 2 as described in § 21–403 of this article, if:

subparagraph.text: the spouse is the sole primary designated beneficiary; and
the member:

sub-subparagraph.text: was eligible to retire; or
was at least 55 years old with at least 15 years of eligibility service.

subsection.text: A death benefit under this section may not be paid for the death of a member of the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System if a special death benefit under § 29–204.1 of this subtitle is payable or has been paid for that death.

A death benefit under this section may not be paid for the death of a member of the Employees’ Retirement System or Teachers’ Retirement System if a special death benefit under § 29–204.2 of this subtitle is payable or has been paid for that death.
This section applies to the surviving spouse of an individual who died while employed as a member of:

paragraph.text: the Employees’ Pension System;
the Teachers’ Pension System; or
the Local Fire and Police System, if the member had not transferred from the Employees’ Retirement System.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a surviving spouse may elect to receive one of the following:

paragraph.text: the death benefit under § 29–202 of this subtitle; or
an allowance equal to the amount payable under Option 2 as described in § 21–403 of this article, if:

subparagraph.text: the spouse is the sole primary designated beneficiary; and
the member:

sub-subparagraph.text: was eligible to retire;
had at least 25 years of eligibility service; or
was at least 55 years old with at least 15 years of eligibility service.

subsection.text: A death benefit under this section may not be paid for the death of a member of the Employees’ Pension System or Teachers’ Pension System if a special death benefit under § 29–204.2 of this subtitle is payable or has been paid for that death.

section.text: If a former member who is eligible for a vested allowance dies before payment of the vested allowance starts, the Board of Trustees, after receiving proof of death, shall pay the former member’s accumulated contributions to:

paragraph.text: the designated beneficiary; or
if there is no designated beneficiary, the former member's estate.

subsection.text: This section applies only to a member of the Judges’ Retirement System who becomes a member on or after July 1, 2012.

paragraph.text: A member may elect to receive a vested allowance if:

subparagraph.text: the member is separated from employment other than by death or retirement; and
the member has at least 5 years of eligibility service.

paragraph.text: A member is deemed to have elected a vested allowance, unless the member requests the return of the accumulated contributions before membership ends.

subsection.text: A vested allowance is a deferred allowance starting at age 60.
A vested allowance:

paragraph.text: is computed as a retirement allowance under § 27–402 of this article on the basis of the former member’s creditable service at the time of separation from employment; and
may be paid in one of the optional forms of allowances under § 21–403 of this article, if at retirement, the member does not have a spouse or child under the age of 18.

If a former member who elected a vested allowance requests the return of accumulated contributions before payment of the vested allowance begins, the Board of Trustees shall return the accumulated contributions to the former member.
When accumulated contributions are returned to a former member, the former member is not entitled to further benefits on account of the former member’s previous membership.

subsection.text: This section applies only to members of:

paragraph.text: the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System;
the Employees’ Retirement System;
the State Police Retirement System; and
the Teachers’ Retirement System.
This subsection applies to an individual who is a member on or before June 30, 2011.
A member may elect to receive a vested allowance if:

subparagraph.text: the member is separated from employment other than by death or retirement; and
subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, the member has at least 5 years of eligibility service.

paragraph.text: A former member of the State Police Retirement System who separated from employment on or before June 30, 1989, must have at least 15 years of eligibility service to elect a vested allowance.
A member is deemed to have elected a vested allowance, unless the member requests the return of the accumulated contributions before membership ends.
This subsection applies to an individual who becomes a member on or after July 1, 2011.
A member is eligible to receive a vested allowance if:

subparagraph.text: the member separated from employment other than by death or retirement; and
the member has at least 10 years of eligibility service.

subsection.text: A vested allowance is a deferred allowance starting at:

paragraph.text: normal retirement age for members of:

subparagraph.text: the Employees’ Retirement System;
the State Police Retirement System; and
the Teachers’ Retirement System;

paragraph.text: age 55 for a member of the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System who is:

subparagraph.text: a correctional officer in the first six job classifications;
a detention center officer employed by a participating governmental unit who has elected to participate in the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System;
an individual serving as a correctional dietary, maintenance, laundry, or supply officer; or
an individual serving as a Maryland Correctional Enterprises officer, officer trainee, plant supervisor, plant manager, or regional manager; or

paragraph.text: age 60 for a member of the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System who is a maximum security attendant at the Clifton T. Perkins Hospital Center.

subsection.text: A vested allowance:

paragraph.text: is computed as a normal service retirement allowance on the basis of the former member’s creditable service and average final compensation at the time of separation from employment; and
may be paid in one of the optional forms of allowances under § 21–403 of this article.

subsection.text: If a member separated from employment on or before June 30, 1990, unused sick leave reported by the member’s employer at the time of separation from employment is creditable service for computing the vested allowance.

paragraph.text: If a former member who elected a vested allowance requests the return of accumulated contributions before payment of the vested allowance begins, the Board of Trustees shall return the accumulated contributions to the former member.
When accumulated contributions are returned to a former member, the former member is not entitled to further benefits on account of the former member’s previous membership.

subsection.text: This section applies only to an individual who:

paragraph.text: is a former member of:

subparagraph.text: the Employees’ Retirement System; or
the Teachers’ Retirement System;

paragraph.text: is eligible to receive a vested allowance under § 29-302 of this subtitle; and
has not elected to receive a benefit under § 29-302 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding § 29-302 of this subtitle, an individual under subsection (a) of this section may elect a lump-sum payment equal to the present value of the individual’s vested allowance if:

paragraph.text: the vested allowance is less than $50 a month;

subparagraph.text: the individual is not a member of the Optional Retirement Program and has terminated any employment with a participating employer for the State; or
the individual is a member of the Optional Retirement Program and has terminated employment with an employing institution as defined in § 30-101(e) of this article; and

paragraph.text: the individual requests a lump-sum payment of the vested allowance on a form provided by the State Retirement Agency.

subsection.text: This section applies only to members of:

paragraph.text: the Employees’ Pension System;
the Local Fire and Police System;
the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System; or
the Teachers’ Pension System.
This subsection applies to an individual who is a member on or before June 30, 2011.
A member is eligible to receive a vested allowance if:

subparagraph.text: the member separated from employment other than by death or retirement; and
the member has at least 5 years of eligibility service.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to an individual who becomes a member on or after July 1, 2011.
A member is eligible to receive a vested allowance if:

subparagraph.text: the member separated from employment other than by death or retirement; and
the member has at least 10 years of eligibility service.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (e), (f), and (g) of this section, a vested allowance:

paragraph.text: is a deferred allowance that begins at normal retirement age;
is computed as a normal service retirement allowance on the basis of the member’s average final compensation and eligibility service at separation from employment; and
may be paid in one of the optional forms of allowances under § 21–403 of this article.

subsection.text: If a member of the Employees’ Pension System or the Teachers’ Pension System separated from employment on or before June 30, 1990, unused sick leave reported by the member’s employer at the time of separation from employment is creditable service for computing the vested allowance.

Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, a former member of the Employees’ Pension System or the Teachers’ Pension System who has separated from employment before the age of 55 with at least 15 years of eligibility service is eligible to receive a vested allowance that:

paragraph.text: begins on the first day of the month following the member’s 55th birthday; and
equals the reduced allowance computed under § 23–402 of this article.
The vested allowance of a former member of the Employees’ Pension System or the Teachers’ Pension System who separates from employment on or before June 30, 1998:

subparagraph.text: is a deferred allowance that begins at normal retirement age;
is computed on the basis of the member’s average final compensation and eligibility service at separation from employment;
shall equal the number of years of the member’s creditable service multiplied by:

sub-subparagraph.text: 0.8% of the member’s average final compensation that is not in excess of the Social Security integration level; and
1.5% of the member’s average final compensation that exceeds the Social Security integration level; and

subparagraph.text: may be paid in one of the optional forms of allowances under § 21–403 of this article.

paragraph.text: A former member of the Employees’ Pension System or the Teachers’ Pension System who has separated from employment on or before June 30, 1998 and before the age of 55 with at least 15 years of eligibility service is eligible to receive a vested allowance that:

subparagraph.text: begins on the first day of the month following the member’s 55th birthday; and
equals the allowance under paragraph (1) of this subsection, reduced by 0.5% for each month that the member’s early retirement date precedes the date the member will be 62 years old.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection and subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, the vested allowance of a former member of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System who separates from employment on or before June 30, 2000:

subparagraph.text: is a deferred allowance that begins at normal retirement age;
is computed on the basis of the member’s average final compensation and eligibility service at separation from employment; and
shall equal the number of years of the member’s creditable service multiplied by:

sub-subparagraph.text: 1% of the member’s average final compensation that is not in excess of the Social Security integration level; and
1.7% of the member’s average final compensation that exceeds the Social Security integration level.

subparagraph.text: This subsection applies only to a former member of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System who:

sub-subparagraph.text: transferred to the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System from the Employees’ Retirement System; and
separates from employment on or before June 30, 2000.

subparagraph.text: The vested allowance of a former member:

sub-subparagraph.text: is a deferred allowance that begins at normal retirement age;
is computed on the basis of the member’s average final compensation and eligibility service at separation from employment; and
shall equal:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: 2% of the member’s average final compensation multiplied by each year of the member’s first 30 years of creditable service; and
1% of the member’s average final compensation multiplied by each year of creditable service in excess of 30 years.

subparagraph.text: This paragraph applies only to a former member who is:

sub-subparagraph.text: receiving a deferred allowance under paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
under the age of 62 years.

subparagraph.text: On receipt of a vested allowance, a former member shall receive a supplemental deferred allowance that equals the difference between:

sub-subparagraph.text: the former member’s vested allowance; and
1.7% of the member’s average final compensation for each year of creditable service.

subparagraph.text: Payment of the supplemental deferred allowance ends when the former member:

sub-subparagraph.text: attains the age of 62 years; or
dies.

subsection.text: This section applies only to an individual who:

paragraph.text: is a former member of:

subparagraph.text: the Employees’ Pension System; or
the Teachers’ Pension System;

paragraph.text: is eligible to receive a vested allowance under § 29-303 of this subtitle; and
has not elected to receive a benefit under § 29-303 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding § 29-303 of this subtitle, an individual under subsection (a) of this section may elect a lump-sum payment equal to the present value of the vested allowance if:

paragraph.text: the vested allowance is less than $50 a month;

subparagraph.text: the individual is not a member of the Optional Retirement Program and has terminated any employment with a participating employer for the State; or
the individual is a member of the Optional Retirement Program and has terminated employment with an employing institution as defined in § 30-101(e) of this article; and

paragraph.text: the individual requests a lump-sum payment of the vested allowance on a form provided by the State Retirement Agency.

section.text: An individual who is a secretary of a principal department or a head of a department, office, or other unit of the State government serving at the Governor’s pleasure has immediate vesting rights on taking office in the State system in which the individual is a member.

subsection.text: In this section, “constitutional officer” means:

paragraph.text: the Attorney General of the State;
the Comptroller of the State;
the Lieutenant Governor of the State;
the Secretary of State; or
the Treasurer of the State.
A constitutional officer who is a member of the Employees’ Pension System:

subparagraph.text: on taking office, has immediate vesting rights in the Employees’ Pension System; and
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, is entitled to a retirement allowance as provided in Title 23, Subtitle 4 of this article.

paragraph.text: The retirement allowance of a constitutional officer who serves at least one full term may not be less than 10% of the annual salary received during the constitutional officer's last term.

subsection.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Consumer Price Index” means the Consumer Price Index (all urban consumers -- United States city average -- all items) as of December 31 as published by the United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics.
“Initial allowance” means a basic allowance or the allowance elected under §§ 21-402 and 21-403 of this article.
“Selection A (Additional member contributions)” means the retirement selection described in § 22-219 of this article.
“Selection B (Limited cost-of-living adjustment)” means the retirement selection described in § 22-220 of this article.
“Selection C (Combination formula)” means the retirement selection described in § 22-221 of this article.
This section applies to a retiree of the Employees’ Retirement System or Employees’ Pension System who:

paragraph.text: retired from the Employees’ Retirement System or Employees’ Pension System on or before June 30, 2009;
before retirement was an employee of the Maryland School for the Deaf; and
before retirement, as an employee for the Maryland School for the Deaf, was a 10–month employee incorrectly classified as a 12–month employee.

If a retiree is receiving a benefit that differs from the benefit the retiree is entitled to receive, the Board of Trustees shall, beginning July 1, 2010, and each subsequent July 1, suspend any annual retirement allowance adjustment the retiree may receive under this subtitle.
Beginning July 1, 2010, and each subsequent July 1, any adjustment to the retiree’s annual retirement allowance described under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be calculated using:

subparagraph.text: for any adjustment calculated under Part II or Part III of this subtitle, the initial allowance the retiree was entitled to receive and not the initial allowance the retiree did receive;

for any adjustment calculated under Part IV and Part VI of this subtitle, the current retirement allowance the retiree is entitled to receive and not the current retirement allowance the retiree is receiving; or

for any adjustment calculated under Part V of this subtitle, both the initial allowance the retiree was entitled to receive and not the initial allowance the retiree did receive and the current retirement allowance the retiree is entitled to receive and not the current retirement allowance the retiree is receiving.

paragraph.text: The Board of Trustees shall suspend any annual retirement adjustment under this subsection until the total amount of retirement allowance the retiree is entitled to receive, including any suspended annual retirement allowance adjustments, equals the total amount of retirement allowance the retiree is receiving on July 1, 2010.

When the total amount of retirement allowance the retiree is entitled to receive, including any suspended annual retirement allowance adjustments, equals the total amount of retirement allowance the retiree is receiving on July 1, 2010, the Board of Trustees shall resume adjusting the retiree’s annual allowance on July 1 of each year in accordance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: If a retiree dies before the total amount of retirement allowance the retiree was entitled to receive, including any suspended annual retirement allowance adjustments, equals the total amount of retirement allowance the retiree was receiving on July 1, 2010, and the retiree has selected an optional form of allowance under Title 21, Subtitle 4 of this article, the deceased retiree’s beneficiary shall receive a benefit calculated on the retirement allowance the deceased retiree was entitled to receive at the time of the retiree’s death and not what the retiree was receiving at the time of the retiree’s death.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, this Part II of this subtitle applies only to an allowance received by a former member, retiree, or surviving beneficiary of a deceased member, former member, or retiree of:

paragraph.text: the Employees’ Pension System if the deceased member, former member, or retiree was an employee of a participating governmental unit or a former participating governmental unit, other than Frederick County, that has withdrawn while a member; or
the Local Fire and Police System.

subsection.text: This Part II of this subtitle does not apply to an allowance or portion of an allowance that is:

paragraph.text: subject to adjustment under Part II, Part IV, Part V, Part VI, or Part VII of this subtitle; or
based on creditable service earned on or after July 1, 2011.

section.text: Each fiscal year, the Board of Trustees shall adjust each allowance as provided in this Part II.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section, the cost–of–living adjustment made under this Part II equals the initial allowance multiplied by a fraction that has:

paragraph.text: as its numerator, the amount obtained by subtracting the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 of the preceding fiscal year from the base year Consumer Price Index described in subsection (b) of this section; and
as its denominator, the base year Consumer Price Index described in subsection (b) of this section.

subsection.text: The base year Consumer Price Index referred to in subsection (a) of this section equals the later of:

paragraph.text: the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 of the fiscal year that preceded the last adjustment; or

subparagraph.text: for a retiree, the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 of the fiscal year in which the retiree was last employed as a member; or

for a former member who elected a vested allowance in accordance with § 29–303 of this title, the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 of the fiscal year in which the former member became 62 years old.

subsection.text: The cost–of–living adjustment under this section may not exceed 3% of the initial allowance.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the total allowance payable in any fiscal year shall be the sum of:

paragraph.text: the initial allowance;
all prior cost–of–living adjustments;
the cost–of–living adjustment provided for under § 29–406 of this subtitle; and
any additional annuity.
In this subsection, “zero–adjustment fiscal year” means any fiscal year when the cost–of–living adjustment provided in § 29–406 of this subtitle is less than $0.00.
For any fiscal year, the total allowance payable may not be less than the allowance paid for the preceding fiscal year.

subparagraph.text: This paragraph applies only to a fiscal year that is not a zero–adjustment fiscal year.
Subject to subparagraph (iii) of this paragraph:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a fiscal year that follows immediately after a zero–adjustment fiscal year, the allowance payable as provided in subsection (a) of this section shall be reduced by the difference between the allowance paid in the preceding fiscal year and the allowance that would have been payable for the preceding fiscal year if the allowance for that fiscal year had been calculated without regard to paragraph (2) of this subsection; and

for a fiscal year that follows immediately after 2 or more consecutive zero–adjustment fiscal years, the allowance payable as provided in subsection (a) of this section shall be reduced by the difference between the total of the allowances paid in each consecutive zero–adjustment fiscal year preceding the fiscal year and the total allowances that would have been payable for each of those fiscal years if the allowance for each of those fiscal years had been calculated without regard to paragraph (2) of this subsection.

subparagraph.text: If the amount of the reduction required for any fiscal year under subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph exceeds the difference between the allowance as provided in subsection (a) of this section for the fiscal year and the allowance paid in the preceding fiscal year, the excess shall be deducted in future years, subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, until the difference is fully recovered.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, this Part III applies only to an allowance received by:

subparagraph.text: a former member, retiree, or surviving spouse of a member:

sub-subparagraph.text: of the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System;
of the Employees’ Retirement System or the Teachers’ Retirement System who elected Selection A (Additional member contributions);
of the State Police Retirement System;
who transferred to the Local Fire and Police System from the Employees’ Retirement System; or
who transferred to the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System from the Employees’ Retirement System and had elected Selection A (Additional member contributions); or

subparagraph.text: a surviving beneficiary of a deceased former member or retiree described in item (i) of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: This Part III applies only to an allowance based on creditable service earned before July 1, 2011, for a former member, retiree, surviving spouse of a member, or a surviving beneficiary of a deceased former member or retiree:

subparagraph.text: of the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System; or
of the State Police Retirement System.

subsection.text: This Part III does not apply to:

paragraph.text: benefits paid in a single payment;
the return of accumulated contributions; or
benefits attributable to additional contributions.

section.text: Each fiscal year, the Board of Trustees shall adjust each allowance as provided in this Part III.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section and subject to § 29–413 of this subtitle, each fiscal year, the Board of Trustees shall adjust an initial allowance by multiplying the initial allowance by the fraction that has:

paragraph.text: as its numerator, the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 of the preceding fiscal year; and
as its denominator:

subparagraph.text: for a retiree, the beneficiary of a retiree, or the surviving spouse of a member, the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 of the fiscal year in which the retiree or member was last employed; or

for a former member or the beneficiary of a former member, the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 of the fiscal year in which the former member reaches normal retirement age.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “zero–adjustment fiscal year” means any fiscal year when the allowance adjusted as provided in subsection (a) of this section results in an allowance that is less than the allowance payable for the preceding fiscal year.
For any fiscal year, the allowance payable may not be less than the allowance paid for the preceding fiscal year.

subparagraph.text: This paragraph applies only to a fiscal year that is not a zero–adjustment fiscal year.
Subject to subparagraph (iii) of this paragraph:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a fiscal year that follows immediately after a zero–adjustment fiscal year, the allowance payable as provided in subsection (a) of this section shall be reduced by the difference between the allowance paid in the preceding fiscal year and the allowance that would have been payable for the preceding fiscal year if the allowance for that fiscal year had been calculated without regard to paragraph (2) of this subsection; and

for a fiscal year that follows immediately after 2 or more consecutive zero–adjustment fiscal years, the allowance payable as provided in subsection (a) of this section shall be reduced by the difference between the total of the allowances paid in each consecutive zero–adjustment fiscal year preceding the fiscal year and the total allowances that would have been payable for each of those fiscal years if the allowance for each of those fiscal years had been calculated without regard to paragraph (2) of this subsection.

subparagraph.text: If the amount of the reduction required for any fiscal year under subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph exceeds the difference between the allowance as provided in subsection (a) of this section for the fiscal year and the allowance paid in the preceding fiscal year, the excess shall be deducted in future years, subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, until the difference is fully recovered.

subsection.text: A retiree may not receive less than the benefits to which the retiree otherwise would be entitled under this Division II.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to retirees of:

subparagraph.text: the Employees’ Retirement System;
the State Police Retirement System; or
the Teachers’ Retirement System.

paragraph.text: A retiree who retired on or before June 30, 1973, may not receive less than the benefits the retiree had received before that date.

subsection.text: This Part IV applies only to an allowance received by:

paragraph.text: a former member, retiree, or surviving spouse of a member:

subparagraph.text: of the Employees’ Retirement System or the Teachers’ Retirement System who elected Selection B (Limited cost-of-living adjustment); or

a former member or retiree who transferred to the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System from the Employees’ Retirement System after having elected Selection B (Limited cost-of-living adjustment); or

paragraph.text: a surviving beneficiary of a deceased former member or retiree described in item (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: benefits paid in a single payment; or
the return of accumulated contributions.

section.text: Each fiscal year, the Board of Trustees shall adjust each allowance as provided in this Part IV.

subsection.text: Each fiscal year, the Board of Trustees shall adjust an allowance by multiplying the allowance for the preceding fiscal year, exclusive of any additional voluntary annuity, by a rate not exceeding 5%, that is obtained by dividing the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31, in the preceding fiscal year by the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year ending December 31 in the second preceding fiscal year.

The adjustment under subsection (a) of this section shall begin the second July 1 after the day preceding the retiree’s date of retirement or the former member’s effective date for receipt of a vested allowance.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the total allowance payable in each fiscal year shall be the sum of:

subparagraph.text: the annual rate of allowance paid during the preceding fiscal year;
the adjustment in allowance provided for under this section; and
any additional annuity.

paragraph.text: (i) In this paragraph, “zero–adjustment fiscal year” means any fiscal year when the allowance adjusted as provided in subsection (a) of this section results in an allowance that is less than the allowance payable for the preceding fiscal year.

subparagraph.text: For any fiscal year, the allowance payable may not be less than the allowance paid for the preceding fiscal year.

sub-subparagraph.text: This subparagraph applies only to a fiscal year that is not a zero–adjustment fiscal year.
Subject to subsubparagraph 3 of this subparagraph:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: for a fiscal year that follows immediately after a zero–adjustment fiscal year, the allowance payable as provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be reduced by the difference between the allowance paid in the preceding fiscal year and the allowance that would have been payable for the preceding fiscal year if the allowance for that fiscal year had been calculated without regard to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph; and

for a fiscal year that follows immediately after 2 or more consecutive zero–adjustment fiscal years, the allowance payable as provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be reduced by the difference between the total of the allowances paid in each consecutive zero–adjustment fiscal year preceding the fiscal year and the total allowances that would have been payable for each of those fiscal years if the allowance for each of those fiscal years had been calculated without regard to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph.

sub-subparagraph.text: If the amount of the reduction required for any fiscal year under subsubparagraph 2 of this subparagraph exceeds the difference between the allowance as provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection for the fiscal year and the allowance paid in the preceding fiscal year, the excess shall be deducted in future years, subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, until the difference is fully recovered.

subsection.text: This section applies to an allowance of:

paragraph.text: a retiree, former member, or surviving spouse of a member of the Employees’ Retirement System or the Teachers’ Retirement System who is subject to Selection C (Combination formula); or
a beneficiary of the retiree or former member described in item (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: benefits paid in a single payment; or
the return of accumulated contributions.

subsection.text: In this section, “effective date of selection” means the date that the member, former member, or retiree first became subject to Selection C (Combination formula) as provided in § 22-221 of this article.
Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, the Board of Trustees shall adjust an allowance described in § 29-421 of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: for creditable service before the effective date of selection, as provided by Part III of this subtitle; and
for creditable service on or after the effective date of selection, as provided by Part VI of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (d) of this section, for a member, former member, or retiree who was subject to Selection B (Limited cost-of-living adjustment) before electing Selection C (Combination formula), the Board of Trustees shall adjust an allowance described in § 29-421 of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: for creditable service before the effective date of selection, as provided by Part IV of this subtitle; and
for creditable service on or after the effective date of selection, as provided by Part VI of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If an allowance is received by a former member, retiree, or surviving beneficiary of a deceased member, former member, or retiree who, while a member, was an employee of a participating governmental unit that has not elected the contributory pension benefit of its employees under § 31-116 of this article or a former participating governmental unit, other than Frederick County, that has withdrawn, the Board of Trustees shall adjust the allowance for creditable service on or after the effective date of selection as provided in Part II of this subtitle.
This Part VI of this subtitle applies:

paragraph.text: on or after July 1, 1998 only to an allowance based on creditable service earned before July 1, 2011, and received by a former member, retiree, or surviving beneficiary of a deceased member, former member, or retiree of the Employees’ Pension System or the Teachers’ Pension System; and

on or after December 31, 2000, to an allowance based on creditable service earned before July 1, 2011, and received by a former member, retiree, or surviving beneficiary of a deceased member, former member, or retiree of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System.

subsection.text: This Part VI of this subtitle does not apply if:

paragraph.text: the member, former member, or retiree was an employee of:

subparagraph.text: a participating governmental unit that has not elected the contributory pension benefit or the Alternate Contributory Pension Selection of its employees under § 31–116 of this article; or
a former participating governmental unit, other than Frederick County, that has withdrawn before July 1, 1998, while a member; or

paragraph.text: the member, former member, or retiree:

subparagraph.text: transferred to the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System from the Employees’ Retirement System; and
did not elect to participate in the Law Enforcement Officers’ Modified Pension Benefit on or before December 31, 2000 as provided in § 26–211 of this article.

section.text: Each fiscal year, the Board of Trustees shall adjust each allowance as provided in this Part VI of this subtitle.
